ship of New Brentford, and stealing therein 40 knives, value 1l. 18s., the goods of
George Simpson, and that Morris had been before convicted of felony.

GEORGE SIMPSON . About half-past eight o'clock in the morning of the 13th of March I left Brentford for London. I have a shop at Brentford, where I sell knives—I left my son-in-law to mind it—I came home at eight at night, and

found a square of glass cut—there was a hole about one and a half inch long and three quarters wide, and a tray that was full of knives in the morning, had only three left in it—about three dozen were gone—I have seen about a dozen of them since, and one of them I can swear to—the tray was close to the window—my door was left open all the morning—I will swear to this one knife—I have lost knives like these fourteen, and I believe these to be mine.

Cross-examined by MR. DOANE. Q. Where do you live? A. At Brent
ford. I sleep at this house—it is in the parish of Hanwell, and in the town-ship of New Brentford—the knives could have been got out very easily by a wire, without putting the hand in—I will not swear that these knives never belonged to Mr. Baines, at Hammersmith—I believe he is here on some trial—I will not swear that these do not belong to any cutler in London.

JOHN HADDON (police-constable T 46.) I received information, and made inquiries—I got into an omnibus, and overtook the four prisoners about six that evening—I got out and saw Morris throw four knives and a pot of marma
lade over a garden—I picked up the four knives—I showed them to Mr. Simpson, and he identified them—I found on Collier seven knives, a pot of marmalade, this piece of wire, and some other things.

WILLIAM MARSH (police-constable T 62.) I went and took Shields to the station—I found on him four knives, and one knife was given me by a boy, which he said was flung away—I have shown them to Mr. Simpson, and he believes they are his.

RICHARD HANCOCK (police-sergeant T 10.) I took Cordwell about ten minutes before nine o'clock the same evening. I went to Paddington after him—he said he had never been to Brentford, and did not know where it was—I told him I took him for a robbery at Brentford, and told him what I had been told by Shields—he said he would tell the Magistrate all about it.
ROBERT NASH (police-constable S 221.) I produce a certificate of Morris's former conviction, which I got from Clerkenwell—(read)—he is the person.
(Collins and Shields received a good character.)

CORDWELL,—
NOT GUILTY .

MORRIS,—
GUILTY
of stealing only. Aged 14.—
Transported for Seven Years.—Parkhurst.

COLLIER,—
GUILTY . Aged 14.

SHIELDS,—
GUILTY . Aged 10.

p.hi:
Of stealing only.—
Confined Nine Days, and
Whipped.

div1.p:
1843.
WILLIAM CLARKE , was indicted
for stealing, on the 28th of March, 4 shillings, the monies of
Thomas Marriott, his master.

THOMAS MARRIOTT . I keep a public-house in High-street, Bloomsbury. The prisoner was in my service not quite a month—I was induced to take him by a person—he said he had got no money—he was employed to take money at the bar—on the 28th of March I marked four shillings and put them into the till—I missed them—after that I marked other money, and on the 2nd of April I sent for an officer and had the prisoner taken—his box was searched, and 5l. worth of silver was found in one bag, and two papers of silver in another box, containing 2l. and some odd shillings in a purse, 7l. 10s. 10d. in all—among it I found these four shillings which I had marked and put into the till on the Tuesday.
HENRY BERESFORD (police-inspector.) I was called, and found these 4s. in the 5l. of silver.

GUILTY . Aged 18.—
Transported for Seven Years.
(There was another indictment against the prisoner.)

1344.
ROBERT BAKER , was indicted
for stealing, on the 4th of April, 1 pair of boots, value 6s.; 2lbs. weight of bread, 3d.; 8 shillings, 2 pence, 4 halfpence, and 1 farthing, the property of
James Gifford.

JAMES GIFFORD . I live in Cross-street, Huntingdon-street, Hoxton. On the 4th of April I left my boots safe—the next morning I found ray breeches, trowsers, waistcoat, and boots behind the door on the bannister—my father sleeps with me—the money stated was in my pockets—some one had come into my room and taken these things—the prisoner did live in the house for some time—there is a man in the house who plays instruments—he is out late, so we leave the street-door unfastened, and on that night I had forgotten to bolt the roomdoor—I had seen the prisoner at six and half-past ten o'clock, before I lost the property, and saw him in the Hackney-road the next morn
ing—I told a policeman—he took him, and found eight shillings and 2 1/2 d. on him, and one shilling I could swear to—this is it—he had told me on the Saturday that the worst had come to the worst, as he had gone to the relieving officer—he pulled out a paper to go and break the stones.

Prisoner. Q. Is it not as likely that the shilling might have got chafed against my tobacco-box as yours? A. No, there is a black mark on its edge, and there are three scratches on the other shilling I had in my bag—the money found on him exactly corresponds with what I had, all but 1 1/2 d.

WILLIAM JACKSON (police-constable N 190.) I took the prisoner, and found on him eight shillings and 2 3/4 d., and some papers and books—the pro
secutor said he lost eight shillings and 4 3/4 d.—he tried to keep his money back, and gave me a shilling, but I found a purse on him, containing seven shillings—he had got the purse up the sleeve of his shirt—the prosecutor immediately identified this shilling, as being chafed and marked—the prisoner had a quan
tity of bread.
Prisoner. I don't know anything about it.

GUILTY . * Aged 29.—
Confined One Year.

1345.
THOMAS JARVIS , was indicted
for stealing, on the 20th of March, 200lbs. weight of lead, value 1l., the goods of
Robert Ford Hayles; and fixed to a building.—2nd COUNT, not stating it to be fixed.—4 other COUNTS, stating it to be the property of
William Hubbard, and William and
Sophia Hubbard.

JOSEPH BUCK (police-constable F 124.) On Sunday evening, the 19th of March, my attention was attracted to a house, No. 2, Bedfordbury, in the parish of St. Martin-in-the-fields—some bricks had fallen from the cornice-work—on the following Monday I went and examined the state of the lead, it was coiled up when I first saw it, but would require cutting before it could be taken away, and the place where the lead had been was vacant—I saw the prisoner at the window—he was within reach of this lead—I went round my beat, and returned about twenty minutes past six o'clock—I then noticed that the lead was beaten out, and flattened down to its place—I came again at half-past seven o'clock—I saw a truck, and the prisoner brought a barrel out of the house, put it into the truck, and pushed the truck round to King William-street, from the front of the house, and left it there—I looked at it, and found the barrel contained some lead—it was much heavier lead than that which I had noticed before—I then saw the prisoner at the barrel—I asked him what he had there—he said "Nothing, it is my own pro
perty"—I was not satisfied, and took him to the station—I went back to the house, went on the roof, and found the dormer had been stripped of lead—the cornice was left as it was—there were four nail-holes in the lead.
and there were four nails on the dormer—they appeared to correspond with the holes—I measured them.

Cross-examined by MR. HORRY. Q. King William-street is some distance from Bedfordbury? A. About half a quarter of a mile—I was standing at the corner of Chandos-street, and Bedfordbury, when he drew the truck away from the door—he had an opportunity of seeing me—I have not had any conversation with anybody who has got up this prosecution, since I was before the Magistrate—I went to Mr. Humphreys the same evening—my evidence was written down before the Magistrate—I did not mention at Mr. Humphreys', for the first time, that I had been to the house, and ex
amined the lead—it was before the Magistrate—I believe I said at Mr. Humphreys', for the first time, that I saw the prisoner move the truck into the back-street—I followed behind him when he was drawing the truck—he had left the truck for about a moment, when I examined it—I did not see where he went to—he did not tell me he was going to have the lead recast—it was at Mr. Humphreys' I first mentioned about the nail-holes—Mr. Elliott was not there at the time—I did not see him there at all—I went to the house afterward—I was in my police dress—my examination before the Magistrate was read over to me—I stated that it contained all I wished to say.
MR. BODKIN. Q. Mr. Humphreys is the solicitor for the prosecution? A. Yes—I attended there, and had my examination taken down—I was desired by Mr. Humphreys to come to his office.

WILLIAM HUBBARD . I am the husband of a lady whose name was Sophia Hayles—she was a widow, and I married her, fourteen or fifteen years ago—she had a son by her first marriage—he is not of age—I and my wife have re
ceived rent for this house in Bedfordbury since our marriage—there was for
merly a tenant named Spronton there—when he went out he let the prisoner in—the prisoner has paid me rent—I have had very great difficulty in getting it from him, and have been obliged to seize his goods several times—at last I was obliged to bring an action in my own name—I have not received any
thing in consequence of that action.

Cross-examined. Q. The prisoner has been in the house twelve years, I believe? A. About eleven—I hold the title deeds of this house—the title to it has not been in dispute, to my knowledge—I went to Mr. Humphreys, at the last examination—I was before the Magistrate the day the prisoner was committed.

WILLIAM ELLIOTT . I am clerk to Mr. James Taylor, who is agent to this property—this house belongs to the son of Mrs. Hubbard before her marriage—he is heir-at-law—Mr. Hubbard and his wife have been in the receipt of the rents since their marriage—an action was brought for use and occupation in consequence of not getting the rent—I attended at the Master's office to tax the costs—the prisoner appeared in his own behalf—the costs were taxed at 100l. and some odd shillings—the prisoner said he was not prepared to pay the amount, he should want time—I told him there was a large arrear of rent due, and he had better give up the premises—he said he was willing to do so—I told him Mr. Hubbard, I had no doubt, would make a great sacrifice if he would give up the possession of the property; he might give it up at Lady-day—he said he would.

Cross-examined. Q. How long is it since you first received rent of the prisoner? A. Between ten and eleven years—he was not to put the house in order, or repair it—I was to write to Mr. Hubbard to know what he would take off.
JOHN BUCKLEY . I am a plumber, in Bath-street, City-road. I prepared

the lead-work for the repair of this house in Bedfordbury some years ago—I have examined this lead—I got into the house the first time after the lead was removed—I noticed the dormer window on the roof—I have since seen the lead in possession of the officer, and, in my judgment, it was taken from the place—I have measured the nails and nail-holes, and it exactly corresponds—I went with the lead to the house, and they refused to let us in—there is about a hundredweight and a half of lead gone—this is not more than three-quarters of a hundredweight—this piece is worth 7s. or 8s., and the whole perhaps 21s.—it would cost a great deal more to replace it.
Cross-examined. Q. But if that had been re-cast, with a little more, and replaced, it would cost less? A. It would depend on the substance—I knew nothing of the premises before the repairs in 1836.
COURT. Q. Does this appear to require re-casting? A. No—it would have lasted fifteen or twenty years.
(The prisoner received a good character.)

GUILTY . Aged 48.—
Judgment Respited.

1346.
MARIA BREDON , was indicted
for stealing, on the 30th of March, 1 bottle, value 2d.; and 1/2 a pint of brandy, 1s. 6d.; the goods of
George Budd, her master; to which she pleaded

GUILTY .—Recommended to mercy.—
Confined Four Months.

1347.
WILLIAM GUNN , was indicted
for stealing, on the 18th of March, 135 newspapers, value 2l. 13s. the goods of
Herbert Ingram and another, his masters.

WILLIAM DANIEL STEVENS . I am warehouseman to Palmer and Clayton, printers of the "Illustrated London News," Crane-court, Fleet-street. On Saturday, the 18th of March, about eleven o'clock in the day, the prisoner came to me for nine quires—he was then in the service of the owners of the paper—about an hour after he came for five more, or 135 copies—I gave him a delivery ticket for them—in the due course of business they should have been delivered to his employers—he did not bring me a ticket—he was to get one part of it signed by the publisher, and bring that part signed back to me—he did not bring the ticket of the five quires back—he did the nine.
Cross-examined by MR. PAYNE. Q. Is it the practice for the person who takes the things to bring back the ticket? A. Yes.

WILLIAM LITTLE . I am publisher of the "Illustrated London News," and live in the Strand. The prisoner was in the proprietors' employ—on Saturday, the 18th of March, the prisoner was employed to bring copies from the printer's—at half-past eleven o'clock that morning he brought me a quantity—I do not know how many—he brought a delivery-ticket which I signed, and delivered to him—he did not bring me any more to my recol
lection, there were so many deliveries—if he brought five quires more I do not remember seeing him more than once that day—he had no authority to sell any copies—135 copies are worth 2l. 13s. 9d.—he did not come back after that Saturday.

SAMUEL WILSON . I am a newsman, in the employ of John William Thomas Newthwaites, of Pope's Head-alley. Between four and five o'clock on Saturday afternoon, the 18th of March, the prisoner came and asked if I wanted any "Illustrated London News"—he said he came from the publisher's—our boy had been at the office, and could not get any copies on account of the sale for them—thinking it strange, we questioned him—he

said he came from Mr. Little's, and if we did not take them he must take them elsewhere—I purchased all he had got, which was forty-seven sheets—I paid him 18s. 9d., or 5d. a paper—I paid the fair trade price for them—from the mode in which he behaved it threw me off my guard.
Cross-examined. Q. Had you ever seen him before? A. Never—I had him in conversation two or three minutes, but I can tell him again by his face.

HERBERT INGRAM . I am one of the proprietors of this newspaper—I have one partner—I engaged the prisoner as errand-boy six or seven months—he met me, and said that Mr. Little said he would not employ him again, he was lazy—I said I had not discharged him, and engaged him again.
Cross-examined. Q. Is this paper registered, like others? A. Yes.

THOMAS SAWYER . I am in the service of my father, a news-agent, of Pope's Head-alley. About four o'clock in the afternoon of the 18th of March, the prisoner came to me to sell some "Illustrated London News"—I bought two quires for 1l. 1s. 6d.—that is a fair trade price.
Cross-examined. Q. Had you ever seen him before? A. Yes, on the Saturday before—these papers are numbered—I do not know the numbers which mine were—I know the dates.
(The prisoner received a good character.)

GUILTY . Aged 18.—Recommended to mercy.—
Confined Three Months.

1348.
JAMES SAMS , was indicted
for embezzlement.

ELIZABETH SADLER . I am the wife of George Sadler, of Queen's-mews, Pimlico. On the 18th of March the prisoner came with some beef—I paid him 6s. 5d.—I do not know who for—I had never seen his master.
Cross-examined by MR. WYLDE. Q. Have you a book in which the items are marked down? A. No—I had a ticket, but no receipt.

JAMES COWELL . I am a butcher. The prisoner was in my service, and it was his duty to pay me the same day as he received money—I sent him with some meat for Mr. Sadler, on the 18th of March, which came to 6s. 5d.—he did not bring back the money—it was his duty to do so.

Cross-examined. Q. Was not he in the habit of taking out meat to sell to customers, which he himself only knew? A. No—he ordered meat, and booked it to Mrs. Sadler—I did not know her then—he was not in the habit of taking out meat, selling it, and giving part of the profits to me—my wife received 2l. odd from him on the 22nd of March—previous to this I had no customers in the Palace till he got them—I knew that he had one there of the name of Bloss—he used to receive the money from them, and account to me for it.
JANE COWELL . I am the wife of James Cowell. I received 2l. 5s. from the prisoner, for a bill he had taken in, but not from Mrs. Sadler.

Cross-examined. Q. What is that book in your hand? A. The book in which I book the meat to my customers—here is the account of 2l. 5s.—the prisoner was not in the habit of taking out meat and selling it on our account until he got the order—he did not bring us many customers—on the 18th he said that he should leave us—I had had no settlement with him after the 18th—I asked him who was to pay the remainder of the money which he took out meat for—it amounted to 2l. 13s. 3d.—he put it down to Mr. Sadler, and others.

GUILTY . Aged 26.—
Confined Three Months.

1349.
MARY SWEENY , and
ANN M'CARTHY , were indicted for
stealing, on the 3rd of March, 3 shirts, value 1l.; and 1 snuff-box, 2l.; the goods of
Charles Antoine Paupierre.—2nd COUNT, stating them to be the goods of Antoine Paupierre.

CHARLES ANTOINE PAUPIERRE (through an interpreter.) I live in Smith-place, Wapping. About half-past eleven o'clock at night, on the 3rd of March, I met the prisoners between Hermitage-bridge and Wapping—they asked me to pay for a pint of beer—I said I had no money, but if they would come to my room I would give them some out of a barrel—they both took my arm, and went home with me—on arriving there the table was laid, and the soup was all ready—they supped, and drank some gin out of a tea-pot, as much as they liked—after supper I said I was going to bed, I felt tired, and if they liked to come to bed they might—M'Carthy went to bed—Sweeny sat by the fire—I went to sleep directly, as I was a little heady—I awoke about three in the morning—I looked right and left, and felt right and left, and felt nobody there—I jumped out of bed, and went to look for my snuff-box—I missed it, and three shirts—I gave information to the police—I went to a public-house in the neighbourhood with the police, and saw Sweeny there—I saw Murray find my shirts and snuff-box in a house.
Cross-examined by MR. PAYNE. Q. What business are you? A. I am foreman to a company for making flour—I have lived in this neighbourhood six months—it was cold gin in the teapot, not hot whiskey.

WILLIAM NORMOYLE , (police-constable H 133.) At four o'clock in the morning of this day, I saw the prosecutor with sergeant Brook, who could not understand him—in consequence of what he told me in his own language, I went to his house—he gave a description of two women—I knew them—I found Sweeny at Skipper's public-house about six in the morning—the pro-secutor recognized her directly as one who had robbed him—I told her he accused her of stealing his snuff-box and shirts—she said she knew nothing about it—she said she had been in the room and supped there, and he made them drunk—I took her to No. 6, Blue Anchor-yard to see after M'Carthy—I stood at the door with Sweeny while the other officer and the prosecutor went in—he found the shirts and snuff-box—the prosecutor said, "They are my shirts," and on unfolding one of them, the snuff-box was in it—I went to the watch-house with Sweeny and the property—I went back to look for the other prisoner, between seven and eight o'clock—Murray knocked at the door, and M'Carthy came out of the back part of the house, partly undressed—I took her as she was going into an opposite house—she said she was drunk, and had no recollection of any thing of the kind.
Cross-examined. Q. Who is Mrs. Stewart? A. She rents the house—it is a house of ill-fame—I have heard Stewart has been convicted.
THOMAS MURRAY (police-constable H 134.) I produce the things. Stewart gave me the key of a box after I took Sweeny—I found these three shirts in a box in her room.

JANE STEWART . I keep this house in Blue Anchor-yard. It is a house where M'Carthy lived for five weeks—Sweeny. I have known for five or six years—she knocked at my door about four this morning—my husband let her in—she said she had had a few words with her husband, and asked to leave a bundle with me, as she was afraid he would tear them—I told her to put them on the table—she said it would be safer to put them in the box—the box was unlocked—she put them in, locked it, and gave me the key—at a quarter past six the policeman came with her—I gave them the key of the box—I said she had been there—M'Carthy was out all that night till she was taken.

Cross-examined. Q. How long have you known M'Carthy? A. Three or four years—I once had six months for striking a man with a quart-pot in my own defence—it is seven yean ago—I did not represent myself as M'Carthy's sister at the prison—I came here to bring her some clean clothes—I passed myself as her sister.
MR. CLARKSON. Q. Could you get more easily at her by saying you were her sister? A. Yes—the turnkey refused me the first day.
(Property produced and sworn to.)

SWEENEY,—
GUILTY . Aged 28.

M'CARTHY,—
GUILTY . Aged 30.

1350.
MARTIN SLATER,
WILLIAM WALSH , and
EDWARD BUXTON , were indicted for
stealing, on the 15th of March, 200lbs. weight of carrots, value 6s.; and 200lbs. weight of pieces of carrots, 4s.; the goods of
William Davis.

JAMES SMITH . I am clerk at Black Lion Wharf, Lower East Smithfield. About the 9th of March the smack Waterloo, Captain Laws, arrived there partly laden with carrots, consigned to Mr. Davis, of Spitalfield's-market—they were carted away by Davis's carts—there were about four sacks left—there were some other carrots from another ship lying at the wharf, belong
ing to Mr. Davis—I saw a man named Coburn, and soon after Buxton and Walsh came to the wharf and took some sacks of carrots away—I do not know how many—there were no carrots belonging to anybody but Mr. Davis on the wharf on the 15th of March.

WILLIAM DAVIS . I was the consignee of these carrots—the three prisoners have occasionally worked for me, but not on the 15th of March—they had no authority to go to the wharf and take these four sacks of carrots—there were some refuse in another sack—they are worth 10s. or 12s.—Slater came to me for money the day before—he said there were a few rotten carrots in the vessel, which the captain said he might have—I said they were not the captain's to give away, if they were rotten they ought to be thrown, away, but being consigned to me, they ought to be put on shore—I told him at his peril to take them.
Cross-examined by MR. DOWLING. Q. Slater was the only person there? A. No, they were all there—I addressed it to all of them—I think they all heard it.

JAMES WOODWARD . I am a green-grocer, and live in Long-lane. On Wed
nesday, the 15th of March, I went to the Black Lion Wharf to cart away some carrots of Davis's—I saw the prisoners there between eight and nine—Slater said, "These are the sacks you can have for 6s."—there were two sacks and a half of carrots, and one sack of refuse—I went away, and said I would not give more than 5s.—my porter came to me, and said, "Give me the 6s.," and I bought them—I asked Davis's man to cart them with the car
rots I bought of Mr. Davis—he said he would not—Buxton and Walsh were on the wharf—Slater said the captain gave them to them for clearing out the vessel—Buxton and Walsh loaded them into my cart, and Slater sold them to me, and took the money—they weighed rather better than 300 cwt. and a half.
Cross-examined. Q. These were rubbish, were they not? A. Yes.
(Slater and Buxton received a good character.)

SLATER,—
GUILTY . Aged 32.

WALSH,—
GUILTY . Aged 25.

BUXTON,—
GUILTY . Aged 30.

1351.
MARGARET CONNOR , and
JAMES CONNOR , were indicted for
feloniously receiving, on the 17th of March, 1 watch, value 2l.; 1 watch-guard, 15s.; 1 locket, 1s.; one pair of boots, 6d.; and 1 cap, 1s.; the goods of
Thomas Spong; knowing them to have been stolen.

ANN SPONG . I am the wife of Thomas Spong, and live in Buckle's Cot
tages, Upper Clapton. I found Elizabeth Loader, took her into the house, and befriended her—she suddenly went away, on the 17th of March, while I was gone out—I missed a watch and chain, and locket—she would have an opportunity of taking them—I never saw either of the prisoners before—Loader never came back.

Cross-examined by MR. PAYNE. Q. How do you know the watch? A. I have had it ten years—here is "Robert Stroud" on the back of it, and one of the hands is turned up at the end—I have the key I wind it up with.

WILLIAM HOWARD . I am a pawnbroker. This watch was pawned on the 18th of March, by Margaret Connor—she first asked 10s., and afterwards 15s.—I lent her 15s.—she said it was her husband's—I asked what he gave for it—she said he bought it before marriage, and she could not say—she was sorry she was obliged at last to part with it, in consequence of the illness of her husband—this guard-chain was pawned by James Connor, on the 20th of March—my brother asked him if it was silver—he said he bought it for silver.

Cross-examined. Q. How long have you known Margaret? A. Nearly six months—the prisoners are husband and wife—they bear a very good cha
racter—James is very ill, and Margaret gets her living by keeping a coffee-stall.

JOSEPH NIFTON (police-constable D 118.) On Monday, the 20th of March, I went to No. 20, Carlisle-street, where the prisoners lived—I saw Margaret first—I said I came about a watch she had pledged—she said the had pledged it; she found it in the Edgeware-road—she produced this cap, and said she found this watch-chain and locket in the cap on the morning of the 18th, close against her coffee-stall—I asked if she knew a girl named Elizabeth Larey, or Loader—she hesitated a few moments, and at last said, "No"—James then said, "We don't know anybody"—Margaret produced the dupli
cate of the property—I told her she had done very wrong in pledging them, if she had found them—I took her into custody—James being very ill, I did not take him—after the examination the next morning I went back to the pri
soners' lodgings with my brother officer, and found this cap, bonnet, boots, and shawl, which she said Loader wore when she absconded.
Cross-examined. Q. Was it after James said, "We don't know any one," that Margaret said she did not know? A. No, before—she made the reply first.
(Property produced and sworn to.)
(The prisoners received a good character.)

MARGARET CONNOR,—
GUILTY . Aged 47.—
Confined Three Months.

JAMES CONNOR,—
NOT GUILTY .

1352.
MARTHA SOANE , was indicted
for stealing, on the 1st of April, 1 half-crown, 4 shillings, 4 halfpence; and 5 duplicates, value 1d.; the pro
perty of
Samuel Soane.

MARY ANN TURNER . I am servant to Samuel Soane, of Bethnal-green. He gave me 6s. 6d. in silver, some copper, and three duplicates, and directed me to get three parcels out of pledge—I gave the duplicates and money to the prisoner on Saturday, the 1st of April—there was a half-crown and four shillings—I told her to be as quick as she could—she ought not to have been above an hour—she did not come back—I did not see her till the Monday
when she was in custody—the prosecutor is the father of the prisoner—he makes me make the money good.
GEORGE MURRAY (police-constable K 68.) I took the prisoner—I told her what for, and I cautioned her—she said a portion of it was on her feet, and showed me a pair of new boots she had on.

GUILTY . Aged 18.—
Confined Three Months.—Three Weeks solitary.

1353.
JANE GEEVES , was indicted
for stealing, on the 25th of March, 2 coats, value 4l. 12s.; 3 pairs of gloves, 1s. 6d.; one handkerchief, 5s.; 1 pet
ticoat, 1s.; and 1 pocket, 1s.; the goods of
Thomas Thompson, her master.

THOMAS THOMPSON . I am a brass-finisher, and live in Westmoreland-place. The prisoner was at my house on the 24th of March—I put my two coats, some gloves, and handkerchief, in the parlour, and I missed them—these are them—they are mine.
GEORGE HANSON . I am shopman to Thomas Smith, a pawnbroker—I took in these coats of a female—I cannot tell who.
JAMES FREWIN (police-constable N 84.) I took the prisoner, and found the duplicate of these coats in her pocket.
Prisoner's Defence. I am sorry for what I have done. I intended to get them out.

GUILTY . Aged 20.—
Confined Three Months.

1354.
WILLIAM HALL , was indicted
for stealing, on the 22nd of March, 1 whip, value 3s., the goods of
James Patten.
JAMES PATTEN . I had a whip—on the 22nd of March I missed it—this is it.

GEORGE KEMP (police-constable N 82.) I watched the prisoner, saw him go round to a cart in Bethnal-green, and go to his companion, who took the whip, and gave it to the prisoner—he walked away and dropped it—I took him.
Prisoner. I never touched it.

GUILTY . * Aged 16.—
Confined Six Months, and
Whipped twice.

p.hi:
Sixth Jury, before
Edward Bullock , Esq.

div1.p:
1355.
ELIZA BLORE , was indicted
for stealing, on the 1st of April, 18 yards of ribbon, value 3s., the goods of
George Simpson.

JOHN HARRIS . I am shopman to George Simpson, who lives in Crawford-street. On Saturday, the 1st of April, the prisoner came into the shop, be
tween five and six o'clock—she asked to look at some black sarcenet ribbons—I showed her some—she threw her cloak over a part of the drawer where the ribbons were—she took up a piece of ribbon, dropped it back into the drawer, and asked the price of another ribbon—I told her 2d. a yard—she threw her cloak again over the drawer, took another piece, and put it under her arm—she said they were too dear, and walked out—I went out after her, brought her back, turned her cloak on one side, and found this ribbon under her arm—it is my master's.
WILLIAM SHRUBB (police-constable D 95.) The prisoner was given into my charge—she begged pardon, and hoped I would forgive her.
Prisoner. I did not intend to take it

GUILTY . Aged 11.—Recommended to mercy.—
Confined Eight Days.

1356.
MARTHA GREENFIELD , was indicted
for stealing, on the 2nd of March, 1 pair of shoes, value 1s.; the goods of
Catherine Nicholls, her mistress.

CATHERINE NICHOLLS . I am a widow, and live in Canonbury-terrace, Is
lington—the prisoner came into my service on Wednesday, the 29th of March,—on the Sunday afternoon she was to go to church—I sent my son to say it was too soon to go then, it was only half-past two o'clock—she then came in, and asked to speak to me—she said, "I have got a pain in my side; will you let me go to the chemist's?"—I said, "Martha, you are not ill; and if you quit my house now, you will not return again"—she went, and I did not see her again till Tuesday evening, about eight o'clock, when she came with a man—I let her in, but not the man—she said, "I have come for my box"—I said, "Your manner has been so strange, and your conduct to mys
terious, that I beg to open that box before you take it away "—she said, "O yes," and opened it with a key, which she took from her side—she com
menced taking the things out—my youngest son held the candle—both my sons were present—she appeared to wish to conceal a small parcel in a worsted handkerchief—she held it in her hand, and took a gown out and threw it over it—she was going to take something else out—I said, "What is that you have underneath the gown"—(I saw there was something shining out)—she said, "Oh, a pair of boots; a pair of shoes that Mrs. French gave me, (who was a mistress she had formerly lived with) and you may come with me to see"—she opened the handkerchief, and I saw these shoes—I knew them to be mine; but they have been defaced in the binding—I had never given them to her, or authorized her to take them—I said, "Oh, you wicked girl; you quite distress my feelings, as a mother, to see you do such a thing"—she threw the shoes on the floor—I took them up, and my son said they were mine—she said, "As a mother, you will forgive me"—I sent my son for a policeman, and while he was gone she said, "They are your's"—they are worth 1s.
Cross-examined by MR. DOANE. Q. Did she not complain that she could not get enough to eat? A. No; my feelings got much excited before the Magistrate, and I insisted on his committing her for trial.
JOHN BROWN (police-constable N 180.) The prisoner was given into my custody for stealing these shoes—she said she did not mean to keep them.
GEORGE NICHOLLS . I am the prosecutrix's son—I heard the prisoner tell my mother, she had put them in her box, seeing her box open in the room.
NOT GUILTY .

1357.
JOSIAH SINGLETON , was indicted for
stealing, on the 24th of March, 327lbs. weight of coffee, value 18l. 8s.; and 3 bags, 2s.; the goods of
Thomas Green; and
CHARLES WILSON
, for feloniously inciting, pro
curing, and commanding
John Singleton to do and commit the said felony; and
ELIZABETH ABURROW
, for feloniously receiving the same, well knowing them to be stolen, against the Statute, &c.

THOMAS GREEN . I am a grocer and tallow-chandler, and live in Leather-lane—on the 23rd of March I entrusted Wilson with a quantity of coffee to be roasted—it was to be returned next morning—about two o'clock in the afternoon of the 24th, he came and said his horse, cart, and harness had been stolen, with my coffee in the cart—I asked where—he said, "From the cor
ner of George-street, Minories"—I asked him why he should take my coffee to the Minories, seeing he roasted it in Old-street—he said he had to call on Mr. Josephs—I asked him for what purpose—he said, "To see if they wanted any coffee roasted"—I said, "Why not leave my coffee first?"—he gave me

no satisfactory reason—I asked for the keys of the stable—he said they were in the cart, and they were stolen—I asked if he kept any man—he said, "Yes, one"—he did not know his name—he called him Joe—I said, "Where does he live?"—he said, "I don't know"—I said, "When did you see him—I said, "—he said, "This morning; he cleaned my harness and loaded the cart"—I said, "What with; my coffee?"—he said, "Yes"—I said, "Which way did you come?"—he said, "At Moorgate; I got a ticket, but I lost it."

Cross-examined by MR. DOANE. Q. Did not he say that he should make it good by instalments of so much a-week? A. He asked if I would accept 10s. a-week—I told him I bettered he stole it, and would not do anything of the kind—I sent to Josephs, and found it was a true account; but they had not seen his coffee, nor did they give him any coffee—they were opening a sewer, which would prevent a cart going dose to the house.

JAMES COOK . I am the prosecutor's shopman—on the 22nd of March I weighed three hundred-weight of coffee to be roasted—it was in three bags—there was a delivery note with it—I desired Wilson to bring it back with the coffee.

MARY BECK . I live in Harrold's-place, John's-row, St. Luke's, which is next door to Wilson's stable—between nine and ten o'clock on Friday morn
ing, the 24th of March, I saw Wilson go into the stable—shortly after I saw Singleton—I afterwards saw a cart and horse go out with some bags—Single
ton was driving—Wilson had gone on a few minutes before.

Cross-examined by MR. ADOLPHUS. Q. What was in these bags you can
not say? A. No. THOMAS WELLER. I live in New-street, Borough-road—I let a cart to Singleton on Thursday, the 9th of March—he returned it on the 24th of March, from a quarter to ten minutes to one—my cart bad my address on it—I did not let him a horse—he took the horse away with him.
Cross-examined by MR. DOANE. Q. When did he pay you? A. He gave me 3s. when he hired it, and 3s. more on the 22nd.

JOHN HALES . I am collector of the City tolls at Moorgate—on the 24th of March, about a quarter past eleven o'clock, there was a horse and cart driven through my gate by Wilson—I gave him a ticket that was marked "Moorgate; City tolls, 243"—I did not take any notice of the load.

GEORGE EDINGTON . I am collector of the City tolls in Jewry-street, Mino
ries—about ten minutes to twelve on the 24th of March, a cart and horse passed through my gate—a ticket was produced, with "Moorgate, City toll" on it—the cart appeared to be laden at the top with coffee—I did not see how many bags—I cannot say who was driving.

Cross-examined by MR. ADOLPHUS. Q. Did you see any coffee? A. No, I could not see what it was—I know by the smell it was coffee—I stopped the cart promiscuously and demanded the toll—I did not notice the cart nor horse, or the man—I jumped up behind and felt the bag—it felt like coffee.
MR. BALLANTINE. Q. Are you able to say it was coffee? A. I think it was—there was a scent of coffee in the cart at the time.
Cross-examined by MR. DOANE. Q. You have been examined about this before? A. Yes—I know Wilson was not the man who was with the cart.

ELIZABETH FULLERTON . I am landlady of the house No. 14, Pearl-row, Blackfriars-road. I know Singleton by sight—between twelve and one o'clock, on Friday, the 24th of March, I saw him come with a horse and cart to my door, to Aburrow, who has my front room—he carried up something, I do not know what—he came down, and drove off—soon after he came back with the horse, took off the harness, and went up stairs—it would take him five or ten minutes to go to the Borough-road.
JOHN MITCHELL (City police-constable, No. 519.) On the 24th of March

Wilson was given into my custody—I went to his stable, in Harrold's-buildings—I got over the wall, and searched them—I produce a paper I found on a nail there—it is the weight and quality of the coffee—I went that night to Jermyn-street, St James's—the landlord let me in—I went into the room pointed out as Wilson's—I found two boys there—I went again at three o'clock in the morning, and waited at the door till Singleton came out—I found he was there by speaking to him—I did not take him into custody till the Sunday afternoon—I found some keys—I have tried them to the stable door, and found they fitted—I went into Aburrow's room, in Pearl-row, Blackfriars-road, and found this bag—it did not contain coffee, but I found some coffee there in a bag—Aburrow was at borne—I asked her who brought the coffee there—she said, Singleton, on Friday, and it was no use denying it—the coffee was under the bed—I took Aburrow on the following Friday.

THOMAS GREEN
re-examined. I cannot say anything about the ticket pro
duced by the officer—I asked Wilson whose cart and horse it was—he said the cart he had hired of Mr. Thomas Wetton, of the Borough, and the horse was his own.

JAMES COOK
re-examined. This is the ticket which was given out, and ought to hare been returned with the coffee—this coffee is similar to that en
trusted to Wilson—it has been roasted—this is the bag I gave him the Java coffee in—it is the original bag—I have the warrant to prove it in my pocket.
NOT GUILTY .

1358.
WILLIAM BROWN , was indicted
for stealing, on the 29th of March, 1 smock-frock, value 2s. 6d.; 2 waistcoats, 5s.; and 1 pair of trow
sers, 3s.; the goods of
Robert Hilliand; and that he had been before convicted of felony; to which he pleaded

GUILTY . Aged 22.—
Confined Twelve Months.

1359.
MARK NAPIER , was indicted
for stealing, on the 3rd of March, 2 sovereigns, the monies of
Thomas Finley.—2nd COUNT, stating it to belong to
Edward Robinson.—3rd COUNT, to
William Rowe.

ELIZABETH FAIRBAIRN . I live in Dalgeish-street, Limehouse. I know Captain Mitchell, of the ship Graham—he sailed last April, and entrusted me to receive 2l. a month to send to his parents, at Hull—I had a note from Mr. Weldon to the owners of the ship at the counting-house in Cheapside for the money—I received it four or five months, on account of Captain Mitchell—I gave the advance note to Mr. Rowe, the clerk—I have known the prisoner since he was a child—he said he would take the trouble to receive the money for me, as he passed the door of the counting-house every day—he received it for me up to the month of March—he brought it me the first time—I asked him how it was he did not bring it any more—he said he sent it away—I said that was very well—I always asked if he had sent it—he said, "Yes"—I asked him about it in March—he said he bad not got it, as there was a little bother about the ship, but he said, "I will get it to-morrow"—he then did not come for three or four days; in consequence of which, I received a letter from him—I know it to be his writing—it said he was going to remove—I became alarmed about the money, and went with an officer in search of the prisoner, and found him in Norfolk-street—he told the officer he had sent it away by post—at the station he said he had not sent it, but made use of it.

Prisoner. Q. Did I know anything of it before you asked me to fetch it? A. I told you I had it—I did not bring the money to your house the week after you had received it the second time and say I had made use of it—the first time you went to the post-office—I never made use of a penny of it in my life—I called at your house on the 4th of March to see you, and you said you had called for the money—I said, "The next money you draw don't send it away,
I want it,"because I wanted to see it—I said I wanted to take a watch out, and that I was back with my rent, and wanted to make ate of it—I was afraid, because I had seen a change in you.

WILLIAM ROWE . I am clerk to Mr. Robinson, a merchant, in Cheapside. Captain Mitchell is captain of the Graham—he is entitled to draw a monthly note in favour of Mr. Weldon—this note was left with Fairbairn—Mr. Finlay leaves the money for Mr. Weldon, and Fairbairn had to receive it for Weldon, the chief officer of the ship—I paid it to the prisoner in March, for Fairbairn—I should have paid it to her if she had come—she was not well when she came the last time, and I said, "Leave the note with me"—she said, "I will send some one for it"—I said, "Leave me the name," and she left, "Napier"—I put the name in the corner—when the prisoner came he answered the descrip
tion, and I paid it him—when I paid the money I parted with the reeponsibi
lity—Mr. Finlay had no other responsibility about it, nor any share in it—if anything, it was the property of Fairbairn.
NOT GUILTY .

1360.
SAMUEL WANTS , was indicted
for stealing, on the 3rd of April, 2 pairs of boots, value 3s., the goods of
Joseph Hopkins; to which he pleaded

GUILTY .—
Confined Three Months.

1361.
HENRY GRANT , and
JOHN WALKER , were indicted for
steal
ing, on the 29th of March, 2 coats, value 3l.; 1 gown, 10s.; 1 shawl, 3s. 6d.; 1 handkerchief, 2s.; 1 ornament, 6d.; 1 blow-pipe, 3s. 6d.; and 1 pair of gloves, 6d.; the goods of
Henry Robinson.

HENRY ROBINSON . I keep the Coach and Horses in Cross-street, Hat
ton-garden. On the evening of the 29th of March, my wife went up stairs to the bed-room to get some change—she called my father out of the club-room, then came down, and called me—I went up, and found Grant under the bed—I fetched the policeman, and when I got him, Grant had been pulled from under the bed—Walker then came in—he called him some name, and said, "You shall not go to the station-house without me; if you take one you shall take both"—these articles were under the bed, and were pulled out with Grant—I had seen them safe under a window in the club-room, which is in the first floor, two hours before—the bed-room is on the second floor—I had seen the prisoners in the club-room before, and I did not observe Walker again till he came into the bed-room, and said, "You shall not go to the station without me."
Walker. Q. Was not I in the club-room when you were called to go up stairs? A. I could not see you then—I saw you afterwards.

MARY ROBINSON . I passed the club-room that evening, but the door was shut—I went to the bed-room, and found Walker under the bed and Grant against the fire-place—I went down stairs, and gave information, and my husband's father went up stairs—I did not go up again—I had left these wings on the table in the bed-room about three hours before I saw the pri
soners—this china figure was on the mantel-piece.
Walker. Q. How can you tell it was me under the bed, you said I had a blue coat on? A. No, you had a jacket—it was you—I did not see your face, I saw your dress—you was lying on your face.
COURT (reading the depositions) "His back was turned towards me, but
I saw his blue coat and dark trowsers; I am sure he is the man." Witness. I believe it was a jacket—it was blue—I am sure he is the man—I am sure the one that was at the fire-place was Grant.

WILLIAM ROBINSON . I went up stairs, and saw Grant under the bed—Walker came in about a minute or two afterwards—I cannot tell from where—I called my son, and a neighbour ran up—he pulled Grant out, and these things, which were all in a bundle under the bed.

HENRY MOORE . I was in the club-room—I heard "Harry" called, and I went up, thinking it was myself—I saw Mr. William Robinson at the door, with a candle—he said, "There are thieves in the room"—I said, "I will find them"—I opened the door, and on looking under the bed I saw Grant—I pulled him out by the legs, and these clothes came out with him—I did not see Walker.

THOMAS DEAN (police-constable G 37.) I took Grant, and gave him to another officer, while I got the property—Grant took out of his pocket this china image, blow-pipe, and pair of gloves—he did not say anything, but Walker said they should not go one without the other, if one went they should both go—Walker resisted.
Walker. Q. Where did you take me? A. In the room.
JAMES CHURCHYARD (police-constable G 174.) I saw Grant take these things out of his pocket.

Grant's Defence. Robinson was about to let his house; the new landlord came that evening to look at it; Robinson invited a lot of men to come and drink free of expense—I was invited by a friend; I had occasion to go down stairs; I did not know the way; I mistook the way up, and got into the room, I suppose.

Walker's Defence. I was not in the room; the policeman says he took me in the room, but it was not till I came down, and the landlord said, "Take him, he is an accomplice;" this woman came out of the room, and she must have seen me if I had come down stairs; I did not know this man before that night.

HENRY ROBINSON
re-examined. I was about to let the house, but did not invite persons, and did not give them anything.

GRANT,—
GUILTY .

WALKER,—
GUILTY .

1362.
HENRY WHITE , was indicted
for stealing, on the 1st of April, 2 sheets, value 3s.; 5 shirts, 2s. 6d.; 3 waistcoats, 3s.; 1 pair of trowsers, 1s.; and 1 jacket, 1s.; the goods of
Charles Spence.
CHARLES SPENCE . I am a seaman, and live in Bromley-street, Stepney. On the 1st of April these things were hanging on a line in my mother's yard—I missed them—they are mine.
CHARLES GILL (police-constable K 59.) I took the prisoner and another boy at the White Horse at Stepney at three in the morning on the 1st of April.

WILLIAM HACKET SHAW (police-sergeant K 2.) About six o'clock in the morning I received these things from Kinche. I examined the premises and saw where they had got over by some remarkable shoe marks—I went to the station, took the prisoner's shoes off, and they fitted exactly with the marks, which all came from Ruston's towards the prosecutor's premises—these things were in a bag.
THOMAS KINCHE . I live in Charles-place, Love-lane. I was at work at Mr. Easton's rope ground at Stepney—Mrs. Ruston asked me if I saw any thing—I turned and saw a large bundle full of clothes.
NOT GUILTY .

1363.
HENRY WHITE , was again indicted
for stealing, on the 1st of April, 3 shifts, value 3s.; 1 table-cloth, 1s.; 1 shawl, 1s.; 6 petticoats, 1s. 6d.; 5 shawls, 1s.; 5 towels, 1s.; 2 caps, 6d.; 2 handkerchiefs, 6d.; and 2 bed
gowns, 1s.; the goods of
John Ruston.

ELIZABETH RUSTON . I am the wife of John Ruston. I left these articles out in my garden on the night before the 1st of April—they were safe at eleven o'clock—I got up at five o'clock the next morning, and they were gone—these are mine.

CHARLES GILL (police-constable K 59.) These four towels, two night caps, and two handkerchiefs I found on the prisoner at three o'clock in the morning, and these other things were found in the bag where Spencer's things were.

Prisoner's Defence. At eleven o'clock at night I saw a lad who was intoxicated; he said if I would see him to Stratford he would pay me, and in going back I saw these things lying down; I put them into my pocket, and the officer stopped me; I told him where I had been.

GUILTY . Aged 17.—
Confined Four Months.

1364.
MARY ANN WILLIAMS , was indicted
for stealing, on the 2nd of Feb., 1 cloak, value 5s.; 1 pinafore, 1s.; and 1 handkerchief, 1s.; the goods of
Mary Matilda Ebdon, from her person.

SARAH LANE . I live in Bride-lane, Fleet-street. On the 2nd of Feb. the prisoner came to me for a lodging, as I had a bill in my window—in a few minutes the person came in who lives in my first floor, and it was agreed that the prisoner should lodge with her, and pay 10s. a week for board and lodg
ing—she then asked me to recommend a man to fetch her boxes from the Commercial Club-house at the back of the Bank—I called a man—she agreed to give him 4s., and he was to fetch them at six o'clock in the even
ing—he came, and asked if she was ready—she said, "Yes," and she asked me to let my little niece go with her—I said she might, and she did—her name is Mary Matilda Ebdon—she had a cloak, a pinafore, and a handker
chief on, which were her own property—I bought them and gave them to her—her father is dead, and her mother is 160 miles off—I gave her these things for herself—the man came back at eight o'clock and said he could not find them—the child could not find her way back to Bride-lane—she got to her aunt's at Clerkenwell at one o'clock in the morning, and had not these things then.

MARY MATILDA EBDON . I recollect going with the prisoner that day. I am sure she is the person—when she got to the top of the lane she took hold of my arm, and said she wanted to make a call or two before the man came—she took me towards Temple-bar, and to Piccadilly—she took me to five public-houses, and at the last one she forced me to drink—she took me up some court, took off my cloak, pinafore, and handkerchief—she then took me further on to the corner of a street, left me, and said she would re
turn in two or three minutes.
FRANCIS MANBY DICKER . I am a pawnbroker. This pinafore and handkerchief were pawned by the prisoner.
Prisoner's Defence. I never took the child's things off; the policeman has a spite against me.
GUILTY .

1365.
MARY ANN WILLIAMS , was again indicted
for stealing, on the 23rd of March, 1 shawl, value 6s.; 1 petticoat, 2s.; 1 handkerchief, 1s.; and 1 pair of gloves, 6d.; the goods of
Fanny Jane Oborne; and 1 sheet, 6s.; the goods of
Susanna Thorpe; and that she had been before convicted of felony.

FANNY JANE OBORNE . I live with my aunt in Leader-place, Westminster. On the 23rd of March the prisoner came there at a quarter to eight o'clock in the morning—she said she had come from Windsor by the steam carriage, and wanted my aunt to recommend a person to go and fetch her boxes, which we did—the shawl was lying there, and she asked me to let her put it on her shoulders, as she was very cold travelling all night—she then borrowed a shilling and got some rum, and had some luncheon—then she got me to write a note to her aunt, at the Marquis of Lansdowne's—we went out, and she asked me to lend her another shilling, which I did—she went away with the man who was to fetch the boxes, and when I got home I missed my flannel petticoat, handkerchief, and gloves, which had been on the mangle where the shawl was.
ELIZABETH HARMAN . I am a searcher at the station—I produce this flannel petticoat which I found on the prisoner.
FANNY JANE OBORNE . This is my petticoat—there is no mark on it, but I have another like it, and it is my own making.

JOHN BARKER (City police-constable, No. 466.) I produce a certificate of the prisoner's conviction, which I got at Mr. Clark's office—(read)—the pri
soner is the person who was then convicted.

GUILTY . * Aged 23.—
Transported for Ten Years.
(There was another indictment against the prisoner.)

1366.
JAMES LEWIS , was indicted
for stealing, on the 23rd of March, 1 coat, value 2s. 6d., the goods of
John Dove.

MARY ANN DOVE . I am the wife of John Dove—we live in Homer-street, Marylebone. On the 23rd of March, I saw this coat, which is my husband's, hanging on the doorpost, just outside, between nine and ten o'clock—I am quite sure it is ours.
GEORGE JOHN RESTIEAUX (police-constable E 49.) On the 23rd of March I stopped the prisoner with this coat, in High-street, St. Giles, about four o'clock in the afternoon.
Prisoner. A person brought it into a room where I was, and told me to go and sell it—I could not sell it, and was coming back.

GUILTY .† Aged 20.—
Confined Six Months.

1367.
FREDERICK ALLEN , was indicted
for stealing, on the 1st of April, 168lbs. weight of iron, value 7s., the goods of
Thomas Murray.

WILLIAM LOWE . I am in the employ of Thomas Murray of High-street, St. Giles—I took some of his iron from the Dutchy-wharf, on the 1st of April—I know this iron which is here—it is my master's, and was on that wharf.
WILLIAM WEBSTER . I reside at Dutchy-wharf—I never gave the prisoner leave to take any iron away, nor lent him any sack to take it with.

Prisoner. Q. Do you deny lending me the sack?—you went into your master's shed, and brought the sack out, and gave it into my hands. Wit
ness. No, I did not.
PETER LOGAN . I am an inspector of police. On the 1st of April, about half-past eight o'clock, I stopped the prisoner coming up the Savoy-steps with this iron in a sack.
Prisoner's Defence. I have been fifteen years employed there, and I very often pick up iron out of the mud and on the wharf. I put it on one side; Webster lent me the sack to take it in.

GUILTY . Aged 36.—
Confined Three Months.

1368.
ANN ALLEN , was indicted
for stealing, on the 1st of April, 1 counterpane, value 5s., and 1 blanket, value 3s.; the goods of
James Smith; to which she pleaded

GUILTY .—
Confined Two Months.

1369.
RICHARD HORRILL , was indicted
for stealing, on the 7th of April, 1 marble slab, value 10s., the goods of
Joseph Browne.—2nd COUNT, calling it 1 piece of marble.

WILLIAM LOVELL . I am in the employ of Joseph Browne, of University-street, St. Pancras. On the 7th of April I saw the prisoner coming out of our front entrance with this marble slab—I went into the show-room, where I had seen it safe, and missed it—I ran out and took him with it, about thirty yards off—I saw nobody else there.
EDMUND NASH (police-constable E 70.) I produce this slab, which I got at Mr. Browne's.
Prisoner. I saw a man standing just in the entrance, and he asked me to take this for him.

GUILTY . Aged 48.—
Confined Three Months.

1370.
FREDERICK STEVENS , and
GEORGE WOOD , were indicted for
stealing, on the 7th of April, 5lbs. weight of bacon, value 2s., the goods of
Robert Edward Wiltshire.

ROBERT EDWARD WILTSHIRE . I live in Cross-street, Wenlock-road, and am a cheesemonger. A little after twelve o'clock, on the 7th of April, a young man gave me information, and I missed three pieces of bacon—I ran out, and saw the prisoners turning the corner—I sent my boy after them—the police
man, in the mean time, brought the prisoners and two pieces of the bacon, which were safe ten minutes before.

JAMES DORMAN (police-constable N 205.) I saw the prisoners running, and each of them had something under his apron—I caught them, and saw Stevens throw down a piece of bacon, and Wood dropped another piece—I took them back to the shop, and one of them dropped another piece—I found a knife on Wood.

Wood's Defence. I picked np the bacon as I came out of the bath door. STEVENS*,—
GUILTY . Aged 13.—
Confined Two Months, & Twice Whipped.

WOOD,—
GUILTY . Aged 18.—
Confined Ten Days, and
Whipped.

1371.
SAMUEL CROUCH , was indicted
for stealing, on the 27th of March, 1 set of harness, value 1l. 10s., the goods of
Charles Maccabe; and that he had been before convicted of felony.

JOHN KNIGHT . I am groom to Charles Maccabe; his stables are at No. 7, Welbeck-street. On the 27th of March I was at the stable—I left at ten minutes to five o'clock, and there was a chaise harness and a box-coat of my master's there then—I returned at nine, and they were gone—this is my master's harness, which was lost that night—I went to the station, and told Harrison what had happened.

ROGER PARTRIDGE . I am a saddler, carrying on business in Thayer-street. The prisoner lives in Marylebone-lane, near to me—he professes to be a hair-dresser and general dealer—he deals in harness, and clothes, and other things—I heard from the police about this robbery on the Monday, and on the Thursday afterwards I met the prisoner in Marylebone-lane—he said he had got some harness, or knew of some—he said something about 25s. as the price—I said, "When I see it I shall know whether I will give it"—on the Friday Woodford brought this harness in a hamper, covered over, and soon afterwards the prisoner came—I frequently buy harness in a hamper, and sometimes pack it in hampers—the prisoner came in, and I passed my judgment on this harness—he asked 25s. for it—I thought it was not worth more than 15s.—I did not tell him what I would give him for it, as I had
scarcely finished my breakfast—I had often dealt with him before, but a policeman had been with me before, to ask if there had been any harness offered.

Cross-examined by MR. WYLDE. Q. This man lives close to you? A. Yes—I have known him ten years—I have bought many things of him, and he of me—he was a respectable man—I never heard anything against him—I never knew anything wrong of him—I know, at that time, there was a phaeton at his door—I knew of his being a barber.

MR. DOANE. Q. Do you swear he was a respectable man? A. I never knew anything but respectability of him—I have heard that he has been transported—I have heard that in Sept., 1840, he was charged with stealing cloth—I did not know that in August last he was taken up for stealing a watch.

WILLIAM WOODFORD . I am a labouring man, and live in Cross Keys-mews. On Friday, the 31st of March, the prisoner asked me to take a basket of harness to Mr. Partridge's shop—I took it, and left it there—Mr. Crouch came into the shop before I came out—I did not see what was in the hamper—he told me it was harness.

THOMAS HARRISON (police-sergeant D 14.) I had an intimation of this from Knight, but it was another officer who told Mr. Partridge—I took the prisoner into custody on Friday morning, the 31st—I said, "Crouch, I want you about some harness, the harness you sent to Mr. Partridge this morning"—he said, "I did send some there"—I said, "How did you come by it?"—he said, "I bought it at the door three or four days ago"—he said he gave 25s. for it—I asked him if he knew who he bought it of—he said no, he did not—I said, "Was any one present when you bought it?"—he said, "No, there was not"—I said it was stolen, and I took him before Mr. Long, the Justice—I gave the same evidence I have now—I was present at the second examination, and the prisoner then called a witness, named M'Laney, who was sworn—he was then examined at the instance of the prisoner—he did not appear at the third examination.

Cross-examined. Q. Did you give testimony at the first examination! A. Yes, and what I said was taken down in writing—the Magistrate did not think there was sufficient evidence, and the prisoner was remanded for me to bring forward the man who carried the harness—on the second occasion I made some addition to my deposition—(read)—"On the second exa
mination, Thomas Harrison, being sworn, says, 'When I took him I asked him if any one was present when he bought it; he said, "No, no one was present"—I forgot to mention that yesterday.' "—THOMAS HARRISON.
Q. That was the addition you made next day? A. Yes—the first hearing was on Friday, the 31st; then we all separated, and on the 1st of April I went and made that addition to my statement.

EDWIN MASON . I know the prisoner—I remember seeing him on the 27th of March, at a person's named Crawford, whose place joins my shop—I met the prisoner there that day, about half-past four o'clock, as near as I can re
collect—Mr. Crawford is a boot-maker—a person came into Mr. Crawford's who has very often called in—his name is Falday—he asked Mr. Crawford if he was going to stand anything to drink—he said he had no objection, and he sent for sixpenny worth of gin—I should say we remained in Mr. Craw
ford's shop, as near as I can guess, for three quarters of an hour—the prisoner remained in the house till near eight o'clock.
MR. DOANE. Q. You went to Mr. Crawford's about half-past four o'clock? A. Yes—his shop joins mine, and I continued there three quarters of an hour

—the prisoner was on the premises till eight—Mr. Crawford's shop and mine join together—it is one house—the prisoner and I, and Mr. Falday, were in Crawford's shop about three quarters of an hour—Mr. Falday was then in my room, which is over Mr. Crawford's shop and my shop, till near eight—I am not an assistant to the prisoner, I am his son-in-law—I am a hair-dresser, and so is he—we are both in the same line of business—he lives two or three hundred yards from me—my shop is at No. 8, Bowling-street—the prisoner was in Mr. Crawford's shop first, and I went in when I heard his voice—Mr. Falday then came in, and then there was 6d. worth of gin sent for—I am sure I cannot say what we talked about—I have not the slightest notion of what I said, or what any one said—I did not sit, I stood—I have known Falday five or six years—I do not know what he is, I only know him from his visiting the shops where I have been—I am satisfied he is not in my line of business—I have always understood him to be a gentleman's servant—he was not dressed in livery, he was dressed as I might be myself—he was dressed in a black coat, and, I think, a black waistcoat—I cannot tell a single thing that was said on that occasion—I cannot tell where I stood in the shop—I am sa
tisfied two or three of them stood—it was in the front shop we had the gin—there was no customer came in while I was there—after we had got rid of the gin, we all went into my room, which is over Mr. Crawford's shop and mine, on the first floor, and we sat down, and played at all-fours—it is my sitting-room and bed-room—we were there, playing at all-fours, from that time till near eight o'clock, and then Falday and Crouch left, and went away—I heard of my father-in-law being charged with this robbery—I did not go and tell the Magistrate about our playing at all-fours—I was not asked any questions—I never told the Magistrate what I could prove—I was there throughout—my father-in-law had a solicitor to attend for him—he never called me—I have lived two years in this shop as a hair-dresser—I do not carry on business in the general line—I never got into trouble myself.

COURT. Q. Who fetched the gin? A. I did myself, in a small black bottle—we drank it out of one glass, what is called a half-quartern glass—we drank it pure, no water nor sugar with it—I had one glass—it was poured out in four different parts—I drank what I suppose would be reckoned a glass, but it was only 1 1/2 d. worth each—there was 6d. worth between four persons—we did not put down 1 1/2 d. each—Mr. Crawford paid for the gin himself, and it was divided into four parts—the glass was filled four times—I could not say who drank first—there were no toasts drank, but merely, "Here's your health"—I said, "Here is your health" to all round, and I think they drank my health all round—we were not three quarters of an hour drinking this gin—not two seconds hardly—we drank it within two or three seconds—that was at the beginning of the three quarters of an hour, almost as soon as we came into Mr. Crawford's shop—I believe he never has but one chair in his shop at a time, unless he sends for one—it was about half-past four o'clock when we went in—it was twenty minutes or a quarter to eight when Mr. Falday and Mr. Crouch left—I borrowed 4s. of Mr. Crouch before they left, which makes me remember the time, as I must pay it again—he lent it me in four shillings—I am not aware that anybody saw him give it me—he gave it me in going down the stairs—Falday and Crouch went together—I did not talk to Crouch publicly about this money—I whispered it to him—we had some beer up stairs, which we played for—we played 2d. a corner each—I do not know who won—I am confident I lost 6d.—we played three or four games—it did not take three hours to play them—we talked, but I cannot recollect anything that we were talking about—we did not talk about any harness—nothing of that sort—Falday did not tell me what he had lately been doing—Mr. Craw
ford

was my partner all the evening, and we played for drink—for porter and gin—I cannot state how many quarts of porter we had—it might have been two or three—I do not know how much gin—I suppose not more than one drop, 4d. worth, or 6d. worth—my wife fetched it—she was not present all the time—there was no other person present—my wife's name is Mary—they did not all know her name, they called her Mason—they saw her bring the gin in—I had a fire in my room—I did not notice who sat next the fire—there must have been two sitting near the fire—I did not sit near it—my wife drank no tea that evening—she had some gin out of the same glass—I do not believe she had any porter—I do not know—we drank the porter out of the quart pewter pot—we had nothing to eat up stairs—I cannot recollect anything we talked about.
MR. WILDE. Q. Good players don't talk much at cards, do they? A. No.

JOHN CRAWFORD . I am a boot-maker, and live at No. 8, Bowling-street, Marylebone. I remember perfectly well, on the 27th of March, seeing the prisoner—it was from four till half-past four o'clock in the afternoon—he came to my house for a pair of shoes I had been repairing—he had not been there many minutes before Mr. Falday came in, and the prisoner's son-in-law came in, and we had a drop of gin, and then we went up stairs and had a game at cards—we went up about five—I should think Crouch left about half-past seven—I did not pay particular attention to the time.

MR. DOANE. Q. You remember this 27th, very well? A. Yes—it was not impressed on my memory from my friend being charged with a felony—that did not make an impression on me at the time—I know it was the 27th, because my boy's birth-day was the day before—that did not make more im
pression on me than my friend being charged—I think I heard of his being charged, last Friday was a week—I do not think they sent to me till then—I have known the prisoner three or four years, and they never let me know of it till last Friday week—I did not think much about it—when I was playing at cards, I had not heard of the felony—my attention was about the cards—we all had some gin.

Q. Your customers coming in now and then? A. Yes, pretty fair busi
ness—we had the gin in my shop where the customers come—when the cus
tomers came in we served them publicly in the shop while the gin was going on—the prisoner and Mr. Falday were customers of mine—no one else came in—I have known Falday, I think, about twelve months—he is a gentle
man's servant—I do not know whose service he is in—he lived with some gentleman in Portland-place—he does not bring me jobs from Portland-place—he has brought me work—I do not inquire particularly where a person lives—I never take things home to any residence—I had seen Falday three or four days before, he came in as a friend—a great many people look in on me—the prisoner came in first on the 27th—I have known him about three years—he came for a pair of shoes that I had been repairing—Falday came in first after him, and then the prisoner's son-in-law came in from his place—Falday came for a pair of boots that I had been half-heeling for him—the prisoner's son-in-law came in for nothing—he naturally followed his father-in-law—our two doors join one another—I was not particularly thirsty.

Q. Who proposed the gin? A. Many people have a little drop of gin—I think Mr. Falday suggested it—he said, "Let us have a drop"—those were about his words—we all agreed to it—Mason fetched it—as far as I can re
collect, I think I paid for it—I paid 6d.—we were in the shop about half an hour—I am sure I cannot tell what we were talking about—I cannot

swear we talked about politics—I cannot pretend to tell what we talked about I am sure—I do not recollect whether Falday had any news to tell us from Portland-place—we talked sometimes about one thing and sometimes another—he asked me about making a pair of boots, and what I would charge—I was sitting on my seat which I work on—I work in the shop—I believe all the others stood—mine is a small shop—after the gin, a hand at cards was proposed—I think Mr. Falday proposed it—I will not be certain who did—we went up stairs to play at cards, into Mr. Mason's room, which is directly over my shop—no one else was there I am certain—we played at "all-fours"—we continued till half-past seven—no one came in during the whole of that time, as far as I recollect, neither man, woman, nor child—Mason had no children there, because his wife took them out—there was no female there—we played for 2d. a corner—I had a partner—we had different partners—Fal
day was my partner first—we changed several times—we might play a dozen games—I would not pretend to say how many—Mason generally fetched the gin—I did not get particularly drunk—he fetched gin more than three or four times—I cannot say how many times.

GEORGE ROBERTS . I am journeyman to the prisoner, and have been so since before last Christmas—I saw some one bring harness to him on the 28th of March, about nine o'clock—I did not hear him make any offer of the harness for sale—I did not hear what was offered—I saw money pass—I did not hear the person who brought it say any thing to the prisoner—I only saw the harness brought and some money paid.

MR. DOANE. Q. Was this in the morning or evening? A. Morning—my master was not taken into custody at the house—I remember his being in custody—I did not hear what for until Harrison came to our house on the Friday morning—the Friday after the Tuesday I heard he was in custody, not for stealing a harness, but for receiving one—Harrison told me that was the charge—I went to the police-court—when Harrison told me about it, I did not tell him a man brought it there—he did not ask me, and I did not tell him—I did not tell until I was called upon—I knew my master was locked up—I went to the Justice the second time, on the Saturday—I did not give evidence—my master's attorney called me as a witness—I was attending, but was not examined—I heard a witness called by my master of the name of M'Laney—he is not here to my knowledge.
Q. Was anybody present when the man brought the harness? A. There was a gentleman present—I was cutting his hair at the time—he was the only person present—I should know him if I saw him.
Q. That gentleman was not the Mr. M'Laney? A. It must be, sir—I was sent for on the third examination before the Magistrate—I was not called to give any evidence at all.
COURT. Q. The policeman came and told you your master was charged with receiving? A. No, he did not.

Q. You told me you knew he was in prison? A. No, I did not—Harrison came to me on the Friday morning—he had not been there before the Friday to my knowledge—he was not there before my master was taken up to my knowledge.
MR. WILDE. Q. You were cutting M'Laney's hair? A. I was cutting a gentleman's hair at the time.

GEORGE WHITE (City police-constable 24.) I am the officer attending in the gallery of this Court—I saw this man come out of the gallery and go and speak to one of the witnesses who is outside this Court now—I heard him say, "You must say you had so many glasses, and what it was drank out
of"—this is the man—(pointing to a person named Charlick)—he said, "You must say what you had it out of, and so many glasses, and that will do."
COURT. Q. Bring in the man that he spoke to. A. This is the man, Falday.

JOHN FALKUS . I produce a certificate of the prisoner's conviction, which I got from Mr. Clark's office—(read)—I was not a witness against the pri
soner on that occasion, but I was present at his trial—he is the same person who was then tried and convicted, and sentenced to death—I was the prose
cutor in another charge against him, and he is the person.

GUILTY . Aged 52.—
Transported for Fourteen Years.
(The witnesses Partridge and Charlick were committed by the Court.)

1372.
JAMES WOODER , was indicted
for feloniously breaking and entering a building within the curtilage of the dwelling-house of
Walter Allen Meriton, on the 20th of March, at Lee, and stealing therein 1 pair of carriage-lamps, value 1l.; 1 box, 6s.; and 1 whip, 4s.; his property.

GEORGE SWAIN . I am groom to Mr. Walter Allen Meriton, who lives in the parish of Lee. On the 20th of March, early in the morning, I went into the garden adjoining master's stable, and saw the prisoner standing close by the wall, which separates our garden from another—I saw a pair of carriage-lamps and the driving-box at his feet, and a pair of my boots on the top of the wall—I went towards him—he drew a knife, and made an attempt to come at me—I went back, and called "Master"—the prisoner got over the wall into an adjoining garden, and made his escape across the road—I looked stedfastly at him, and am sure he is the man—I went to the coach-house, and found master's carriage-lamps and driving-box gone, which had been safe the night before—the stable is in the yard between the two houses—there is a wall right round, enclosing the garden, coach-house, and dwell
ing-house—I had locked the front door of the coach-house over night—it was about five minutes before six o'clock when I found the prisoner in the garden.

Cross-examined by MR. PRICE. Q. Was it not much earlier? A. No—I am quite sure it was before six o'clock—I did not look at the clock, but I heard the clock strike directly after—I had never seen the prisoner before—he was dressed in a cloth cap, with a leather front to it, and a white frock on—that is a common dress for a bricklayer.

WALTER ALLEN MERITON . I was formerly a captain in the merchant service, and live at Lee. On Monday, the 20th of March, I saw a person running away from my premises, across the high road—he appeared to have a white short frock on, very clean—I saw the prisoner before the Magistrate next day—he appeared to be dressed the same, but the frock was much darker than when I saw him about 100 feet from my house.
Cross-examined. Q. You never saw him before? A. No—I could not swear to him—I only saw him behind.

CHARLES NINTMO . I am a policeman. I examined the prosecutor's premises, on the 20th of March, at half-past eight o'clock in the morning—I traced some steps in that garden and the adjoining one, and found part of a whip in the adjoining garden.
JOHN CARPENTER . I am a policeman. I apprehended the prisoner about a quarter to nine o'clock, on the Monday evening, at the Hare and Billett,

Blackheath—he said he would accompany me anywhere I pleased, as he had done nothing he was ashamed of—I asked where he was at six that morning—he said he was going to his work, that he left his house at ten minutes be
fore six, and got to his work about five minutes after six, at Mr. Russell's buildings, in Lee-road—that is half or three quarters of a mile from the pro
secutor's—I took him to the prosecutor's, and as soon as Swain saw him he said, "He is the man I saw in my master's garden"—the prisoner made no reply.

Cross-examined. Q. Did you know he worked at Mr. Russell's? A. I never knew what he worked at—I know his brother to be a bricklayer's labourer—I never knew anything against him—I told the prisoner he was suspected of having committed a robbery—he said, "Me?"—I said, "Yes, and if you know yourself innocent you will not mind accompanying me to near the Lion and Lamb, Lewisham"—he said he would accompany me any
where, and went—a frock nearly down to the knee is a very common dress—they are slop-frocks—I should know the prisoner from the groom if I saw them apart.

WILLIAM WOODER . I am the prisoner's brother—we live together, at No. 5, King-street, Blackheath. On Monday morning, the 20th of March, he got up at twenty minutes to six o'clock—I called him—he sleeps in the back-room, the next room to me—I told him to make haste, and dress himself, which he did in three or four minutes—we both left the house together, and went to the same place to work—we got to work a little after six—we continued at work together all day, till night—Mr. Meriton's house is about a mile or more from ours, and about a mile from where we work—the pri
soner had only been employed at the work on the Saturday and Monday—he ought to be at his work at six o'clock.

COURT. Q. Who saw you at work there that day? A. All the men in the building—we have two clocks in our house, one up stairs and the other down—it would be, I should say, a quarter of a mile out of our way to go to Mr. Meriton's, instead of going direct to our work—I know the time we started—I looked at the church clock on Blackheath-hill—it was exactly ten minutes to six then—it is close to our house, on the right coming down the hill, one side of the clock is towards the road, and one side towards Black
heath—Mr. Bath is foreman of the bricklayers there, but we were at work for the plasterers—Mr. Emly is foreman of the plasterers—he is here—my brother had no knife—he borrowed a chisel of the carpenter to cut his meat with, both on the Saturday and Monday—Mr. Emly and others saw him using it.

JAMES JACKMAN . I am a bricklayer's labourer, and live in Essex-place, Blackheath-hill—I am a neighbour of the prisoner's. On Monday, the 20th of March, I was going across Blackheath, and saw the prisoner and his brother going across the heath, about two minutes before six o'clock, near the Hare and Billett—I knew them both very well for three years and a half or four years—they are hard working industrious boys—the prisoner has been out of work a great deal lately, and I have also—they were going to
wards Lee—six o'clock was our time to be at work.

COURT. Q. Where were you going to work? A. At Mr. Couchman's, the upholster, in the village—I was wheeling a barrow—when they passed me they were walking in the ordinary manner—they appeared going to their work—I generally saw them going to their work—we often go together—I kept a particular account of this day, because I was told I should have to be here—I went before the Magistrate, but was not called.

THOMAS BULL . I am out of business; I live at the Horse and Groom, on Blackheath-hill. I have known the prisoner since August last—he is a bricklayer's labourer, and has worked for me in that capacity. On the morn
ing of the 20th of March I was standing at my front door, at ten minutes to six o'clock, and saw the prisoner and his brother go quickly out of the yard—I have not the shadow of a doubt about the time—I had looked at the clock—the brother had a brown coat, and a bundle under his left arm—the prisoner had a sort of dirty-white frock and cap on, which is a very common dress—they were going swiftly to their work, in the direction of Blackheath-hill.
