COURT. Q. What kind of cap had he? A. A dirty-brown kind of cloth cap—there might be a piece of leather in front—I did not pull out my watch when they passed, but saw the church clock—they came out of the Horse and Groom yard—there is a direct road through there to the place where they lived.

WILLIAM HINDES . I am a master plasterer, and live at Lewisham. The prisoner's brother is employed constantly for me, and I employed the prisoner at intervals—I employed him on Monday, the 20th of March on the Lee-road, at Mr. Russell's buildings—there is a new detached cottage there—it is from three-quarters of a mile to a mile from Mr. Meriton's—you come to the Lee-road first from Blackheath—they would not go near Mr. Meriton's in coming to their work, it would be quite out of their way—they would be nearer Mr. Meriton's when at my house, than they would be afterwards—I expected them both at work that morning—they overtook me, as I was going, at the upper end of Lee-lane—they came close behind me, walking very fast—I heard them talking together—I did not speak to them—that was about two minutes after six—I am very positive to the time, as I heard the clock strike six—they live nearly a mile and a half from the work.

COURT. Q. What clock are you speaking of as striking six? A. Lee church clock—the prisoner had on a sort of dirty-white smock-frock, and a fur cap very much worn, to the best of my recollection—I dined on the premises—I noticed that the prisoner ate his breakfast, on the 18th of March, with a carpenter's chisel, and on the 20th he ate his dinner and breakfast with a carpenter's chisel—there are but few of us in the building—the master I work for ate his dinner with a lath—I had a knife—some of the other men ate with knives—the prisoner's brother ate with a knife with one blade and a half; one blade was broken.

FRANCES WOODER . I am a widow, and live at Blackheath; the prisoner is my son. On Monday, the 20th of March, he was in bed at twenty minutes before six o'clock—I have a clock down stairs, and my son has one up stairs—my clock goes very nearly with the church clock on the hill—the prisoner passed through the room I sleep in, opened the door, and shut it after him—I was in bed—I looked at the clock before he got up, and it wanted twenty minutes to six—I look to see that he goes regularly to his work—I almost always look at the clock—I am quite sure I did so that morning.

GEORGE SWAIN
re-examined. It was Lee church clock that I heard strike—it is not half a mile from our house—when the prisoner was brought by the officer to Mr. Meriton's premises I was there, and said I considered he was the man I saw that morning—I said so loud enough for the prisoner to hear me—I did not hear him say a word—I spoke loud enough for all in the house to hear me—the man I saw that morning had on a kind of brown cloth cap.
NOT GUILTY .

1373.
JOHN HAWKESWORTH , was indicted
for a robbery, with vio
lence, on
James Magee, on the 27th of March, putting him in fear, and taking from his person, and against his will, 1 cap, value 4s. 6d.; and 1 pair of gloves, 8d.; his goods.

JAMES MAGEE . I am in the band of the Royal Artillery. On the 29th of March, about ten minutes past eight o'clock, I was on Woolwich Common, in company with a female, on the public footpath, going from Woolwich towards the Cadets'-barracks—I saw two men pass me on the right—after they had passed a considerable distance, they turned back, and opened out, and I felt a rope round me very soon—I extracted myself from it, and pulled myself towards the one that held it—I had hold of it—then the other one, in company with two men, came on me behind—I did not see them previously—they pulled me down, and ill-used me in a shameful manner, they kicked me, and said, "Gag him, give it him"—they allowed me to get up, but, I think, through fear; for when I got on my feet, I observed a gentleman at a short distance, and they ran away—when I got up, I missed a black glazed uniform cap, and a pair of gloves which were inside—I did not know any of the persons then—I can identify the prisoner—I am quite sure he was one—it was rather dark—I had seen the prisoner several times before, but never knew who he was, or what his name was—he must have been one of the two who passed me—I think he was the one that had the rope—I am quite sure he was one of the four.

THOMAS HUNTER . I live in Jackson's-lane, Woolwich Common. I was not on the common on Wednesday last—about half-past eight o'clock, as I was coming up from the barracks towards the White-gate, I met the prisoner, with a cap on his head—it was like a soldier's cap—the top was torn off—it was glazed round the peak—I had known the prisoner by sight before—I am quite sure he is the person I saw with the cap.

LOUIS FERDINAND KELLY . I live at Woolwich—I have been in the Artil
lery, and was discharged through a hurt. The prisoner lives next door to me—last Thursday, between eleven and twelve o'clock, I saw him in the barrack yard fronting his father's house, with a lightish-coloured cap on his head—I looked at it—it appeared to me to be the cap now produced—it was similar to it—when he saw me he took the cap off, and put it under his arm.

WILLIAM GLADWIN (police-constable R 112.) I apprehended the pri
soner on Thursday afternoon, between two and three o'clock, at his father's house—his brother and sister were also in the house—he was concealed under a bed—the windows were all barricadoed up, the shutters and door fastened—I got in by taking two or three tiles off the roof—I told him I apprehended him on a charge of assaulting and stealing a cap from Mr. Magee, one of the bandsmen—he said there were others concerned as well as himself—I took him to the station—next day I searched a privy in front of his father's house, ten or fifteen yards from it, in the yard, where the prisoner was at work in the morning, and there found this cap.

JAMES MAGEE
re-examined. I can swear this is my cap—my name is in two places in the inside of it—the whole of it was covered with glaze, similar to this front, but the top is torn off.
Prisoner's Defence. I had nothing to do with the rope—I never had the cap in my possession.

GUILTY . Aged 17.—Recommended to mercy.—
Confined Six Months.

1374.
HENRY JAMES HAMMOCK , was indicted
for unlawfully obtain
ing 2 loaves of bread, some butter and cheese, by false pretences.
JOSEPH RICHARDSON . I am a grocer, and live in the New-road, Woolwich. On the 18th of March the prisoner came and asked for a two-pound loaf, some

cheese, and half-a-pound of butter, which I served him with—I did not know him before—he said they were for Mr. Edgar, who had dealt with me some
times—on the 21st he came again, and asked for a two-pound loaf, half-a-pound of butter, and half-a-pound of cheese—he said he was to have Dutch cheese, because it was the best he had had the day before—he said they were for Mr. Edgar, and took them away.

Prisoner. Q. Have I not been at your shop half a dozen times? A. I have not seen you—you did not say, "Let me have a loaf, butter, and cheese, and I will get Mr. Edgar to pay for them on Wednesday"—I asked how Mr. Edgar was, and you said, very well, but he was not at home—I should not have given him the things had he not said they were for Mr. Edgar.

WILLIAM EDGAR . I am a linen-draper, and live at Woolwich. The pri
soner was in my employ eleven months, and was discharged about two months ago—he was not in my service on the 18th of March—I had frequently sent him to Mr. Richardson's, but he never went—I did not send him there on the 18th or 21st of March—I had forbid him my house before that.
JAMES PARRY . I am a policeman. I took the prisoner on the 29th of March.
Prisoner. I was out of place, and in distress; I thought I should be able to get Mr. Edgar to pay for it.

GUILTY . Aged 18.—
Confined Three Months.

1375.
JOHN DAVIS , was indicted
for stealing, on the 16th of February 1 coat, value 12s.; the goods of
Thomas Pacey Birts.

HENRY BERRY . I am a baker, and live at Woolwich. On the 16th of February I was in the street at Woolwich—I saw the prisoner takes coat from inside the door of Mr. Birt's shop—he walked away with it—I ran into the shop—I afterwards saw him again in High-street, and pointed him out to the policeman, who took him—he is the person.

THOMAS TAYLOR . I am in the service of Mr. Thomas acey Birts, a pawnbroker and salesman in Woolwich. On the morning of the 16th, I hung a coat inside the door—I missed it—it is here—(produced)—I know this is it.
EDWARD PALMER . I am a policeman. I took the prisoner into custody—he said he had not been there, he had been at the Golden Cross for two hours, in company with the waiter.
FREDERICK LEIGHTON . I am assistant to Mr. Davis, a pawnbroker—this coat was pledged by a woman on the morning of the 17th.

Prisoner. He said, when the coat was brought forward, that he could not swear to it, he had many more of the same pattern—I was not near the place where the coat was stolen—I had been up at the Golden Cross and was walk
ing down from the market-place.
(The prisoner received a good character.)

GUILTY . Aged 23.—Strongly recommended to mercy.—
Confined Two Months.

1376.
THOMAS WAVER , was indicted
for stealing, on the 30th of March, 1 loaf of bread, value 3d., the property of
William Henry Brown, to which he pleaded

GUILTY . Aged 24.—
Confined One Month.

1377.
JAMES MOORE , was indicted
for stealing, on the 19th of March, I dead fowl, value 2s., the goods of
James Nicholson.
GEORGE WILLIAM WHITE . I am shopman to James Nicholson, he is a poulterer at Woolwich. The prisoner and another party came in while I

was shutting up the shop about two o'clock on Sunday morning, the 19th of March—I served the other person with steaks and sausages—I did not like the prisoner's movements, and when the other had given me a shilling in pay
ment, I went round the counter, and missed a fowl—I saw the head of it under the prisoner's jacket, and after I had given change I went after them—I brought the prisoner back, and charged him with it—he said he did not know anything about it—I called the policeman, went with him, and found the fowl at Mr. Moss's door, which the prisoner had passed just before I took him.
Prisoner. Q. Was I not at the door of your shop when you accused me? A. No, I brought you back from where you had got to—you had a piece of timber in your hand, not under your arm.

JURY. Q. Are you quite satisfied that you saw him with the fowl under his arm going out? A. Quite—the door is narrow, and you are obliged to turn rather sideways to get out—it was not wood that he had under his arm, the wood was in his hand.

JOSEPH HOLLOWAY (police-constable R 137.) I was called, and found the prisoner in Mr. Nicholson's shop—I afterwards went and found the fowl at the step of the next house—the witness identified it—the prisoner first said he knew nothing about it, but when Mr. Nicholson was called, he said he did it for a lark, and when he was taken to the station-house, he said it was his own.

Prisoner. Q. Do you say that I said I took it for a lark? A. Yes, you had a stick of wood in your hand—I did not say I would help you up—I said you had better be careful not to say anything to criminate yourself.

Prisoner's Defence. The man and I went into the shop; the witness was serving him; I came to the door to go out; I did not go two steps from the door, and was returning again, when he came and accused me of taking a fowl; I said I knew nothing about it; I was not going to run away; if I had taken it it is not likely I would have returned.

GUILTY . Aged 27.—
Confined One Month.

1378.
CECILIA DRYDEN , was indicted
for stealing, on the 14th of Dec., 1 bed, value 10s., the goods of
William Webb: also, on the 14th of Dec., 1 fender, 1s. 6d.; 1 set of fire irons, 1s. 6d.; and 1 pair of boots, 1s.; the goods of
William Webb; and that she had been before convicted of felony; to which she pleaded

GUILTY . Aged 44.—
Transported for Seven Years.

1379.
WILLIAM STANTON , was indicted
for stealing, on the 16th of March, 1 waistcoat, value 10s.; 1 pair of trowsers, 1l.; and 1 coat, 2l.; the goods of
George Stanton: also, on the 23rd of March, 1 looking-glass and frame, 2l., the goods of
Benjamin Berry Stanton; and that he had been be
fore convicted of felony; to which he pleaded

GUILTY . Aged 18.—
Transported for Seven Years.

1380.
WILLIAM O'BRIEN , was indicted
for stealing, on the 2nd of March, 1 shawl, value 10s., the goods of
Matthew Williamson; and 1 pair of shoes, 5s., the goods of
Alfred Jannery; to which be pleaded

GUILTY . Aged 30.—
Confined Three Months.

1381.
WILLIAM WHITE , was indicted
for stealing, on the 30th of March, 1 loaf of bread, value 3d., the goods of
William Henry Brown, to which he pleaded

GUILTY . Aged 27.—
Confined One Month.

1382.
ROBERT SMITH , was indicted
for stealing, on the 6th of March, 1 shilling, and two sixpences, the monies of
Elizabeth Skinner and another; and that he had been twice before convicted of felony.

ELIZABETH SKINNER . I am single, and am in partnership with my brother. We keep a baker's shop on Blackheath. On the 6th of March, I had occasion to leave the shop and go into the kitchen—I returned and found the prisoner with his hand in the till—when he saw me he instantly left the shop—I cried, "Stop thief"—I found the till half open—I am quite sure the prisoner is the person—I had examined the till about three minutes before, there was then one shilling, two sixpences, and some copper in it, and when he left all the silver was gone.
Prisoner. She told me to run after the chap. Witness. No; he is the one who took the money from the till—there was another taller than him outside.

JOHN CARPENTER (police-constable R 84.) I was on duty—I saw the prisoner running from the prosecutrix' shop—I ran and overtook him at the railway—I said, "Hallo! where are you going?"—he said, "I am looking after a lad who has robbed a till."
JURY. Q. How far was he from the prosecutrix' shop when you first saw him running? A. About 200 yards.

Prisoner. She told me to run after the chap, and I did, and the officer took me—this woman is not the chief witness—the fishmonger that saw the prisoner run away is not here. Witness. He never was brought in question at all—it never was mentioned about him.

JAMES BROOK (police-constable L 118.) I produce a certificate of the pri
soner's conviction, which I got from the Clerk of the Peace for Surrey—(read)—the prisoner is the person—he had three months' imprisonment, and was whipped.

Prisoner. It is false, I never was in prison but once before. Witness. I am sure he is the person—he was tried with another person, and each of them reversed their names—the prisoner gave his name as Robert Hall.

EDWARD PRIME (police-constable B 85.) I produce a certificate of the prisoner's conviction, which I got at Mr. Clark's office—(read)—the prisoner is the person—he was tried in the Old Court—I am sure he is the person.
Prisoner. That is right.

GUILTY . Aged 19.—
Transported for Fourteen Years.

1383.
GEORGE PAXTON , was indicted
for stealing, on the 17th of March, 1 pair of shoes, value 7s., the goods of
John Miller, from his person.
JOHN MILLER . I am a seaman. I was at the Lord Duncan, at Deptford, on the 17th of March—I got very drunk, and lost my shoes from off my feet in the public-house—these are them.
HENRY BRADLEY (police-constable R 250.) I met the prisoner at past eleven o'clock, on the 17th of March—he had this pair of shoes, which he said he found in the road.

WILLIAM THOMAS ARTHUR (police-constable R 202.) I saw the prisoner coming out of the tap-room of the Lord Duncan, wrapping something in a handkerchief, and putting it under his frock—there was no one else there—I went into the room, and saw the prosecutor asleep, without his shoes—when the prisoner was brought in with the shoes, I knew him to be the man I had seen.

GUILTY . Aged 57.—
Confined Two Months.

1384.
WILLIAM SHRIMPTON , was indicted
for stealing, on the 20th of March, 1 coat, value 7s., and 1 waistcoat, 1s.; the goods of
Richard War
wickshire.
RICHARD WARWICKSHIRE . I am a green-grocer, and live in Harding's-lane,

Woolwich. On the 20th of March, about nine o'clock, I missed a coat and waistcoat, which I had seen safe about seven o'clock the same evening at the foot of the bed—my house was not locked—my wife was out—I believe this coat and waistcoat are what I missed.
ANN ALLEN . My husband keeps a clothes-shop in Woolwich. At half-past eight o'clock that evening, the prisoner brought this coat and waistcoat, and I bought them of him.

Prisoner's Defence. On the Saturday I was at my uncle's (the prosecutor) and I asked him to lend me 7s. or 8s.; he said, "No; but he had a coat and waistcoat at home, that I could go and take when I liked."

RICHARD WARWICKSHIRE
re-examined. I told him so a day or two before.
NOT GUILTY .

1385.
JAMES CRAWLEY , was indicted
for unlawfully uttering coun
terfeit coin.

RICHARD JOB FRANCIS . I am the son of Rebecca Francis, who keeps the Bull-inn, Shooters'-hill. On the 17th of March, the prisoner came to me for half-a-pint of beer, I served him—he put down a bad 6d.—I saw it was bad—I cut it in two, and kept one half, and he took the other half away—I am sure he is the man—when he took one half he knocked the other off the counter—he asked for a candle, my mother would not let him have it, and he went away without it—I picked the other half up the next morning, and put it into a china cup, and at last gave it to the policeman—on the 22nd, the prisoner came again for half-a-pint of beer—he put down another bad 6d.—I showed it to my mother—I told her it was bad—he laid down another sixpence, which was good—I went for a policeman, and gave him into custody, with the sixpence.

Cross-examined by MR. DOANE. Q. Did not you pick up one-half of the sixpence you cut, and the prisoner the other? A. No—on the second occa
sion the prisoner said, "Is it a bad one?"—I said, "Yes," and he paid another.

REBECCA FRANCIS . On the 17th of March the prisoner came—he gave my son a sixpence—it was cut in two, and one half fell down—he wanted a light, and I would not let him have it—on the 22nd he came again—he paid my son a bad sixpence—my son brought it to me—I said it was bad—I cut it with a penknife, sent for a policeman, and gave him the sixpence and the piece.

WILLIAM BECK (police-constable R 214.) I was sent for, and took the prisoner—I told him it was for uttering a counterfeit sixpence, and said he had been there the week previous—he denied it, and said he came from Maid-stone that day—I received this sixpence and half a sixpence
MR. JOHN FIELD . I am inspector of coin to the Mint. This sixpence is a counterfeit, and this is half of another counterfeit sixpence.

GUILTY . Aged 47.—
Confined Six Months.

1386.
JAMES DOUGLAS DIXON , was indicted
for stealing, on the 2nd of April, 1 purse, value 6d.; 1 crown-piece; 9s.; 1 sixpence; 3d.; and 6 halfpence; the property of
Charles Jacobs: to which he pleaded

GUILTY . Aged 18.—
Confined Three Months.

1387.
FRANCES FILLMORE , and
LOUISA WILMOT , were indicted for
stealing, on the 3rd of March, 1 purse, value 6d.; and 16 sovereigns; the property of
Thomas Brown, from his person; and that Fillmore had been before convicted of felony.

THOMAS BROWN . I am master of the ship Regent, and live at Shields—on Friday, the 4th of March, I met Fillmore in a house at Woolwich—I had sixteen sovereigns in a purse in my pocket—I did not take it out while she was with me—I went home with her at nine o'clock, and saw Wilmot—I gave her a sovereign to go and get some rum—I took out my purse—Wilmot came back with some rum and gin—I put my purse in my pocket again—the pri
soners drank some gin, and I some rum—we left the room and went up stairs—I was taken very ill, and went to sleep, as if I was dead, about ten minutes after I drank the rum—I only drank two wine glasses of it—I am in the habit of drinking the same quantity, and it never had such an effect upon me before—the prisoners did not drink any rum, and I did not drink any gin—I awoke about two o'clock in the morning, and found myself on a bed—I was alone—I felt for my purse, and it was gone—I stopped there till morn
ing—Fillmore was in bed in the same room, and in the morning I told her she had taken my purse—she said she had not—my clothes were on—I saw Wilmot in bed down stairs in the morning—I told her one of them had taken my purse—she said she knew nothing at all about it—I then told the police
man, and went away—I gave Wilmot a shilling before I went away.
Cross-examined by MR. HORRY. Q. Had you been drinking before you met Fillmore? A. Yes; I had had a pint of porter—I was quite sober.

CAROLINE WEST . I am the wife of John West, and keep the Marquis of Granby at Woolwich—on the 23rd of March Wilmot came for half a pint of rum—she gave me a sovereign—I gave her 18s. 2d. change—in about a quarter of an hour she came for a quartern of gin and a quartern of pepper
mint.

GEORGE HARRIS . I am a policeman. On the 4th of March I received information, and went after the prisoners—I overtook Fillmore and another girl at Rochester—I told Fillmore she was charged with robbing a captain of a considerable sum of money—they both began to cry—Fillmore said she should not have robbed the captain, if it had not been for somebody else, that she held the candle while the other person robbed the man, and she had 3l. of the money—I found in her hand a purse and six sovereigns—I went back, and found Wilmot had absconded from Woolwich—I afterwards apprehended her at Greenwich—I told her she was charged with being concerned with robbing the captain at Woolwich—she said, "Oh, my G—d."
Fillmore. I robbed the man—Wilmot is innocent.
WILLIAM TOMLIN . I produce a certificate of Fillmore's former conviction, which I got from Maidstone in Kent—(read)—I was present at the trial—Fillmore is the person.
(Wilmot received a good character.)

FILLMORE,—
GUILTY . Aged 18.—
Transported for Ten Years.

WILMOT,—
GUILTY . Aged 32.—
Confined Twelve Months.

1388.
REUBEN MAY , was indicted
for stealing, on the 17th of March, 23 sovereigns, the property of
John Miller, from his person.

JOHN MILLER . I am a seaman, and live in Ratcliff-highway—on the 17th of March I was paid off from the Columbine, at Chatham—I left there about ten o'clock that morning, and three more mates came as far as the Bull's Head public-house with me—I met with the prisoner—he had a one-horse fly; and he agreed to take our party to London for 10s. each—there were four

of us—we did not take the omnibus, as we thought it would be more conve
nient to go by ourselves—we stopped at the Bull's Head at Dartford, and dined there—the prisoner was in the carriage from Chatham to Dartford—we had paid 10s. each to go to London; and notwithstanding that, my three shipmates went by the coach from Dartford on to London, and they took my bag with them, which contained 30l. in notes, besides my clothes—I engaged the prisoner to take me after the coach, and I gave him a half-sovereign more—I was then spreeish, about half way; but I knew what I was about—I and the prisoner got into the carriage again, and the driver, the same man who had driven before, sat outside on the box—the prisoner was inside, along with me—we overtook the coach at Shooter's-hill, and I got my bag—I then pro
posed that the prisoner should drive me to Blackwall, and I paid him an extra sovereign to drive me there—he told me I could not expect him to drive me there without more money—he had had 2l. 10s. before, and I gave him another sovereign—I had then twenty-five other sovereigns in my purse—the prisoner was then sitting inside the fly, and had an opportunity of seeing my money—I put my money into my purse, and put the purse inside the breast of my shirt—I then buttoned the front up—I drank a drop of rum out of a bottle that I had provided myself with from Chatham; and the prisoner drank some—I then fell asleep, and when I came to I found myself in the Lord Duncan public-house, in the Broadway, Deptford—I then felt for my money—the purse was left, but all the money was gone; and my shirt was unbuttoned—the prisoner never took me to Blackwall; but I found myself in a strange house at Deptford.

Cross-examined by MR. WILDE. Q. You are a sailor, and you and three of your friends got paid off? A. Yes, I was soberish—I had drank some beer, and so on, in the early part of the morning—I had some about eight o'clock in the morning—I found myself alone at the Lord Duncan—I had put my purse in my shirt—I cannot tell at what hour I did that—it was getting dark in the afternoon—I do not recollect being shot out at the Lord Duncan—I found myself there—I do not know at what hour he brought me there, but I started about ten o'clock in the forenoon, and it was about eleven or twelve at night when I found myself at the Lord Duncan—the prisoner left me there—I do not recollect driving the van—I know Wilson—he and I did not go off in the van—he was with us—there were four of us in the van when we started, the prisoner made five, and Wilson drove—when we got to Dartford three of my shipmates left, and there was no one but me and the prisoner riding inside—I lost my shoes at that house, but that was after I lost my money—I was fast asleep, some one took my shoes off, and that did not a wake me.

ELIZABETH WARE . I keep the Lord Duncan, Broadway, Deptford. About seven o'clock in the evening, on the 17th of March, I heard a scuffle in my tap room—I saw the prisoner and another man putting the prosecutor on the bench in the tap room—I do not know whether the other man was Wilson—I asked the prisoner why he brought the drunken sailor into my house—he said he had been directed by him to do it, he had been paid off at Chatham, he was directed to leave him there, and he could not take him any further—I said I should not allow him to leave him, unless he gave me a satis
factory account about him—I asked the prisoner if he was paid—he said he was, and he knew the prosecutor very well—he said, in the course of conversa
tion, that he belonged to Blackwall, and he was going there, but he was directed to put the prosecutor down there—I said that unless he gave me a satisfac
tory account of his employer and himself I should not let him leave him, and he did so very willingly—I then asked him to hold the prosecutor up while

I searched his pockets—he said he believed the prosecutor had got money, and he hoped I would take care of it—he said he thought it was in his bosom; that he heard it rattle—he then held him up, and I noticed that the bosom of the prosecutor's shirt was open; and I made an observation that I was sure he had been wrongly dealt with, from the appearance of his shirt being rumpled—I then saw a string, and found a small leather bag round the pro
secutor's neck, and the bag had been torn down—a sovereign was hanging out of it, and one sovereign was at the bottom of it—I said, "Here is further proof that the man has been robbed"—I said it seemed unreasonable for him to put his cash in such a purse as that, and I was sure he had been wrongly dealt with—the prisoner said it was impossible, for there had been no one in the fly but himself, or "ourselves"—I found a half-crown in the prosecutor's waistcoat pocket, and 5d. in coppers in his jacket pocket—he was in a very helpless state; he could not sit on his seat—I saw the key of a watch hang
ing at the back of his trowsers, and found the watch attached to it—the pri
soner was then gone—he went away after he gave me the address, and said he should be there the next day with some more sailors, as there was another ship to be paid off—after I had searched the prosecutor the prisoner said, "Now you have searched the sailor, I should rather you searched me"—I said, "No, there is no occasion for that"—he showed me a shilling, a penny or three halfpence, and said that was all the money he had about him—he asked me particularly to take care of him, as he knew him very well, and had known him for years—he gave me his own name and address, and his em
ployer's, and the sailor's, and where the sailor would be going when he got sober—about midnight the prosecutor came to—I had kept him by himself entirely—I took his bag, and after he got sober he directed me to look in it, and I found six 5l. notes in it—on the Sunday following the prisoner called in with another one, who I understood was his driver, who drove the van and drove Miller up—he asked me if I had seen any thing of the sailor—I said I had, and he was still with us—I told him the sailor had been robbed, and his complaint was that he had been robbed in the van—he said it was impossible—he did not stay—he said he was in a hurry to go, as his horse wanted to go back—he said he would call the next day and hear further about it—I told him we had found the watch which we had searched for before he left.

Cross-examined. Q. How long had the sailor been in your house before you searched? A. I searched him directly, before the prisoner left him—he was lifting him on the seat and I was endeavouring to wake him up—there were three labouring men sitting in the other end of the tap room—I heard them come in—I went, and the prisoner and another man were lifting the prosecutor on the seat—I do not know who the other man was—he went out directly—I know a man brought in a bag directly after—I did not see the prosecutor arrive, and I cannot tell how long he might have been outside, but when I heard the scuffle I went out—I can say that they had then been in about half a minute, and they were drawing him along.

WILLIAM THOMAS ARTHUR (police-constable R 202.) On Sunday, the 19th of March, I took the prisoner on Blackheath—the prosecutor was with me—I told the prisoner he was charged with robbing the sailor of twenty
three sovereigns—he said, "Me?"—I said, "Yes"—he said, "That is false"—I said, "There was no one else riding inside the fly"—he said he had not been inside, "but" he said, "I might have put my legs over the front to have got in, but not that I am aware of—the prosecutor said, "Why did not you take me to Blackwall, instead of putting me at that public-house in a strange place?"—he said, "I did not engage to take you to Blackwall but to Lon
don."
Cross-examined. Q. Did you give him any caution before you argued

with him? A. I told him it was no use arguing with me—I told him what he was charged with, and he began talking to the sailor—I said, "Don't say a word till you get to the station"—I merely told him what he was charged with.

HENRY WILSON . I live in High-street, Chatham, and am a van driver for Mr. Baker. On the 17th of March I was at Chatham, and agreed to take four sailors to London for 10s. each, which they paid—the prosecutor was one—I came to Dartford—the prisoner came to take care of the things—there were four big bags and other articles beside—he came with me—he was sometimes inside and sometimes out—I drove—we stopped at Dartford and dined there—three of the sailors went on by the coach—the prisoner, the prosecutor, and I remained behind—we pursued and came up with the coach on the Chatham side of Shooter's Hill, and the prosecutor got his bag which had been carried by mistake to the coach with the other luggage—the prisoner rode from Shooter's Hill first inside and then out—he rode inside to keep the prosecutor quiet—he was mad and pulled the curtains and broke the top—he was drunk.

Q. Till you got to Blackheath was the prisoner inside with the prose
cutor? A. Yes—we then took up a passenger—I do not know who he was—the sailor must have seen that passenger get in—he got in and rode to Deptford and paid me 1s.—I did not go to the Lord Duncan, but to the Rose and Crown—the sailor then said, "This is London; I wont go no further"—he got out and had a pint of ale at the Rose and Crown.

Q. You did not undeceive him that he was not in London, though you had taken his money to drive him to London? you let him get out under the delusion that he was in London? A. He was mad and would not go—he took hold of the horse—the prisoner and the sailor went away from the Rose and Crown—I had a call aside and lost my van—it was a very foggy night—I could not find it—I went down to Chatham by another conveyance—the prisoner got out on this side Shooter's Hill—he remained inside till he got to Black heath—the sailor came out and in too.

Cross-examined. Q. How did he do that? A. By crawling over the front of the carriage—he did that several times—he wanted to drive—he whip
ped the horse from time to time—they broke my whip between them—they all wanted to drive, and then the prisoner bought me another whip—we got to the Rose and Crown between seven and eight—I did not go out from the Rose and Crown—I left my van somewhere there—they hired this van for themselves for 2l.—that is the usual fare—the prisoner got the job, and called me—three of them ran away from us at Dartford on account of this sailor being so obstreperous—they staid at the Rose and Crown about ten minutes—they wanted to stop at every house—the public-house before the Rose and Crown, is the Bull, at Shooter's-hill, they got out there—the public-house before that, was the Fox and Hounds, they got out there, and staid about ten minutes—I know the prosecutor disposed of money to people, as he was going along—I saw him throw some sort of money to children and poor people as we went through villages, as the children came up to the van, cry
ing out—the prosecutor threw money, and the others too, and he did so after the others left.

COURT. Q. Did you go on to London? A. No, I went on towards London, and passed the Lord Duncan—I went on towards New-cross, where I saw another conveyance—I asked the driver if he had seen my van—he said, no, and I went back by him—I had previously been back to the Rose and Crown, and could not find my van.

ELIZABETH WARE
re-examined. The Rose and Crown is about ten mi
nutes' walk from my house, just over Deptford-bridge—I do not know whe
ther
Wilson is the man that I saw in my house with the prisoner and the prosecutor, but he is the man who came with the prisoner on the Sunday.

JOHN MILLER
re-examined. This is my bag—it was hung round my neck—I shut it up close, and secured 25l. in it.

(William Baker, a van proprietor and butcher, of Rochester, the prisoner's employer; Mace Hopkins, a hackney-man, of Rochester; George Harris, of the Bull Inn, at Rochester; and William Record, a coach-maker, of Bedford, gave the prisoner a good character.)

GUILTY . Aged 29.—
Transported for Ten Years.

1389.
WILLIAM JOSEPH ALLSOP , was indicted
for stealing, on the 1st of March, 2 pairs of boots, value 1l. 10s., the goods of
Edward Towill.

MARY WALTERS . I am shopwoman to Edward Towell, of the Borough. The prisoner has been his shopman, on and off, for four or five years—on the 1st of March he was in the shop with me—the woman who usually brings his dinner, came in about half-past eleven o'clock with a basket—she set it on the further side of the counter, on a chair, and came and talked to me—I saw the prisoner cross the shop, take some boots off a nail, and put them on the end of the counter—I afterwards missed them—I saw the prisoner shuffling about at the bottom of the counter, and thought something was not right—he took up the basket, and was handing it to the woman—he said, "You may as well take this basket home now"—I said, "No, you don't take it out till I have looked at it"—I looked into it, and found a pair of Blucher-boots and a pair of Wellington's, which are here—they are my master's property—I took them out of the basket, told the woman to go out of the shop directly, and told the prisoner also to go—I did not see him again till he was in cus
tody.
WILLIAM GRAHAM . I am a policeman. I took the prisoner into custody, and told him the charge—he said nothing.
(The prisoner received a good character.)

GUILTY . Aged 43.—Recommended to mercy.—
Confined Three Months.

1390.
MICHAEL ISAACS , and
JOHN LEWIS , were indicted for
break
ing and entering the warehouse of
Edward Arnold, on the 18th of March, at St. Olave, Southwark, and stealing therein, 2,570lbs. weight of rags, value 21l.; and 21 bags, 14s., his property.

WILLIAM CRUTTENDEN . I am a carman, and live in Cherry-garden-street, Bermondsey. I know the two prisoners—Lewis was formerly in Isaacs' ser
vice—on Friday evening, the 17th of March, between seven and eight o'clock, Isaacs came to me—he said he wanted me to move some rags from Mr. Ar
nold's to Mr. Pewtress's—I was to be at Arnold's at six o'clock in the morning—he came to me next morning about a quarter past five with another person, not Lewis—it was the same person that came with him overnight—he told me to go to Mr. Arnold's with the van to shift some rags to Mr. Pewtress's—I was to back the van alongside Mr. Arnold's warehouse, and load them in—I had been to Mr. Arnold's warehouse before for Isaacs—he dealt there—I have taken rags there for him to sell—I went with the van—the other went with me—he was a lad—I got to Mr. Arnold's warehouse about six o'clock, and backed

my van under the crane—I saw Lewis there when I got there—I was in the van—Lewis put the rags into the van—he hooked them on to the crane, which low
ered them down—I did not see Isaacs at that time—there was about fourteen bags, about 16 cwt. I should guess—I saw nothing more of Lewis till he got to Mr. Pewtress's—he did not come into the van that I saw—I did not see Isaacs—I went down the Borough, round by Horsemonger-lane—I did not go through any turnpike—I went the straight road—I got to Mr. Pewtress's about seven o'clock, and found Lewis and the other man there to take the bags out of the van into the warehouse—I looked across the road and saw Isaacs waiting there—there was nobody to do business on Mr. Pewtress's part—I saw nobody but a young lad going in at the side door—the rags were pitched down against the wall of Mr. Pewtress's warehouse—it was about seven o'clock in the morning—I have not been paid—I was to have had 1l.—the fair price for the job was about 7s. or 8s.—I went about a mile alto
gether—Isaacs proposed to give me 1l.

Cross-examined by MR. PAYNE. Q. How came you by Horsemonger-lane? A. We went round by the low side, and turned to the right, that brings us very near Mr. Pewtress's side door—Isaacs did not speak to me at Mr. Pewtress's—he did not interfere with the arrival of the van, nor go into Mr. Pewtress's that I saw.

WM. TAYLOR SMITH . I live with my father at No. 3, South-street, Maze. On Saturday morning, the 18th of March, I got up about half-past five o'clock—there is a gate before my father's premises—as I stand there I can see Mr. Arnold's premises—I live adjoining them—about half-past five o'clock I was at my father's gate, and saw Cruttenden there with a van and the prisoners—I knew Isaacs before, and have often seen him—Lewis was helping him up at the top crane—Isaacs remained inside the warehouse while Lewis lowered the rags down on the crane into the van—I saw Isaacs helping Lewis with the crane—it winds inside, and wants steering outside to drop the goods into the van—Isaacs did not come out at all—he remained inside, but I had a clear view of him, and am certain it was him—the van went away about half-past six o'clock full of rags—after it was loaded Lewis jumped into the van, and it went up the Maze—I saw nothing more of Isaacs—I cannot tell how he got out—I directly told my mother what I had seen, and that I knew the persons—before I left I tried the premises—I pushed the half-batch door on the ground-floor, and found it was open, it was closed but not fastened—it gave when I pushed it—it was not fast within—there was none of Mr. Arnold's men there.

Cross-examined by MR. PAYNE. Q. How old are you? A. Going on for twelve—I go to school—I was standing against our gate which joins Arnold's premises, on the same side of the way—the top warehouse where Isaacs was is three floors up—Lewis jumped from the second floor—I looked up from the gate, and saw Isaacs at the third floor, and he came to guide the crane down to the van—I was standing close to the wall of the building—it was only when the crane was pushed out that I had a view of Isaacs—I never had a quarrel with him.
Cross-examined by MR. BALLANTINE. Q. Have you seen Isaacs there before? A. Yes, several times, bringing rags to Arnold's.

CAROLINE WALDUCK . I am the wife of John Walduck, of South-street. Smith lives next door but one to me—Mr. Arnold's warehouse joins our house—on Saturday morning, the 18th of March, I was up at a quarter or half-past six o'clock—I heard a noise in Mr. Arnold's warehouse—it attracted my at
tention, as the men do not come quite so early—I went to the bottom of the court to inquire the time—it was such a noise as a truck would make—when
I went to the door I saw the van—I did not take any particular notice—I saw one sack of rags dropped into the van—I did not see who lowered them—Cruttenden was there.

MICHAEL RYAN . I am in the employ of Mr. Brewer, a marine store-dealer, of Bermondsey-wall. I know Isaacs well—on Friday, the 17th of March, about seven o'clock in the evening, I left my employer's premises—I met the prisoners and another party—the two went on before, and I got into conversation with Isaacs—he was talking about the badness of his business, the depression of trade, and several other matters, which I cannot exactly re
collect—he did not mention the name of Arnold—he mentioned the name of Teddy—he said, "I should" or "would you like to have a load of Teddy's fines"—I did not know what he meant at first—I took it to be equivalent to what he had done before with Arnold, getting some of his goods, and not paying for them—I did not know what he meant till I heard of the robbery—there are certain rags called fines—I have been in the rag line, and was brought up to it from my boyhood—I did not make any answer—there was nothing tran
spired, except I said, "You will be getting yourself transported for life"—I think I said so afterwards.

EDWARD ARNOLD . I was at my premises in the Maze, on Friday after
noon, the 17th of March, about two o'clock—it is in the parish of St. Olave, Southwark—Wheeler and Bryan are my servants there—Wheeler had the keys—there are three floors, and each floor has folding doors—the one on the ground floor is cut in two, and forms a hatch—they are fastened at night by two bars going across, one towards the bottom, and the other at the top—above the top bar is an aperture for a letter-box—if anything is introduced from the outside into the letter-box, the bar might be turned—the bar goes across the two doors, and is only fastened at one end—it is a shifting bar—I came to the premises next morning, about a quarter past nine o'clock, and found them broken open, and the property all gone—it is worth about 21l.—the price of seconds is 16s. a cwt.

JAMES WHEELER . I am in Mr. Arnold's service. I was in the premises on Friday, the 17th of March, and left about half-past six o'clock, or a quar
ter to seven—before I left I secured the warehouse—I had the keys—there is a door at the side, which I locked when I went away—I secured the lower warehouse door with the two bars—I came to the warehouse next morning about a quarter or twenty minutes after seven, opened the side-door, and let myself in—I saw the half-hatch door of the front warehouse a little open, went in, and found the top bar on the ground, which would allow the upper hatch of the door to be pushed open—a man could then get in, and unfasten the doors inside—I went into the middle floor, and missed fifteen or sixteen bags of rags—there were twills among them—we had three bags of fines—they were not taken—they were all safe at seven o'clock on Friday evening when I left—twills are new pieces, they are more valuable than others—I found the hooks of the crane outside—they ought to have been inside—I supposed somebody had been using the crane—the rags were kept in the middle floor—it would require the assistance of a second person to get them out—they would want one man in the middle floor to guide the crane to the cart, and one up above to work it.

SAMUEL PEACH PEWTRESS . I am a partner in the firm of Pewtress and Son (it is not the firm of Pewtress and Son in Gracechurch-street, a separate firm altogether) I live at No. 67, Newington-causeway, where we carry on business—I came down on Saturday morning, at eight o'clock, and saw some rags standing in the street, against the house—I gave 13s. a cwt for them, which is the price we always give for second rags, and no more, whether they are better or not—I do not know the parties they were bought of—I inqured

of our foreman who they were, but not of the parties—I paid 14l. 15s. for them—part of them were sent down to the mill on the Tuesday after the Saturday this took place—the rest have been mixed with others—they were mixed at the time they were delivered—they were shot out among other loose rags in the warehouse—I had been informed before that the rags were coming.

WILLIAM HENRY JOHNSON . I am in the service of Pewtress and Son. On Saturday morning, the 18th of March, I got to the warehouse about seven o'clock, I found a van waiting there, and Cruttenden and Lewis with it, and a third man, whom I have not seen—it was not Isaacs—I said to Lewis, that he had come early with them—he said he had, because the young person wanted to go into the country—he asked me whether he could leave them by the warehouse door—I said he could if he liked—I refused to take them in—he asked if I could weigh them—I said, I could not till about ten o'clock—they were unloaded, and left by the warehouse door, outside—I rang the bell and went in—about five minutes after I went to the door again, and the van was gone, and the rags lying against the wall by the warehouse door, in the street—about eight o'clock I received the foreman's directions to weigh them—they weighed 22 cwt. 3qrs. some old pounds—I did not pay for them myself—my fellow-servant was by at the time—they called again.
Cross-examined by MR. BALLANTINE. Q. Have you told us the very words Lewis used? A. Yes, to the best of my recollection—I weighed them, and my fellow-servant took the account of them on a slate.

WILLIAM PANNELL . I am foreman to Pewtress and Son. I got to the warehouse about a quarter to eight o'clock on Saturday morning, and saw the rags standing against the wall, and saw Lewis and another man—the other man asked me if I could weigh them—I had seen Lewis and the other man two days previous—they came into the shop, and Lewis said "This person has got some rags coming up from the country," and asked what price we could give for some fine rags—I said 23s.—they asked what time I could take them in in the morning—I said we should not be able to take them in before nine or ten o'clock, I thought—next day the other man came alone—I afterwards saw the rags weighed by the boy—they weighed 22 cwt. 3 lbs. odd—I paid 14l. 16s. 3d. for them to the tall man in the fustian dress—he was with Lewis in the morning, but he came round into the shop, and I paid him the money—I did not know their names at the time, and did not ask.

COURT. Q. Did he give no receipt? A. We do not have a receipt—we take the amount on a slate—it is not a general rule for us to give or take bills—a great many come in during the day—it is not customary to ask the names of persons—the tall one came the second day, and said the principal part of the rags were seconds which had come up, and the others would be in on Monday.

Cross-examined by MR. BALLANTINE. Q. When did you first remember that Lewis had been to you two days before? A. I did not know whether his name was Lewis—I recollected it when I was before the Magistrate—my deposi
tion was read over to me—they would not allow me time to mention it—Mr. Pewtress and I have not been talking this matter over—I have told him these two persons came two days before—Mr. Pewtress saw them as well as myself—I have had no conversation with him since about it, nor ever alluded to it—part of the rags were sent down to the mill, and some are now in the warehouse—they have not been given up to the prosecutor—part of them went to the mill either on Tuesday or Friday—this has been the usual habit of dealing since I have been with Mr. Pewtress—we have not been in the habit of giving or taking invoices.
COURT. Q. Where were these rags shot? A. In the warehouse, among

others of the same description—we keep the different sorts separate—we should not have shot them among the fines—there is a rapid demand for them at the mills sometimes—we supply the mills—they do not remain with us long—we only keep two sorts of rags, fines and seconds.

MR. CLARKSON. Q. Were these twills or seconds? A. We do not make any distinction between twills and seconds, nor in price, they are mixed all together—when these came in in the morning I looked at them, and took some of the twills to Mr. Pewtress before I weighed them, and said I thought there was a mixture of woollen among them, and asked him to look at them—he looked at two or three pieces, and said, "I don't think they are quite so good as they ought to be, but as there are not many of them let them go," or else we should have picked them out and returned them—the woollen would not do, if there was a great deal—twills are of a little more value than seconds; but we have but two prices, one for fines and one for seconds—we use all as seconds that are not fines—we do not sort them—they are sorted as they come in to us—if they are not right we pick them out at the time.

JAMES TIDMARSH . I am a policeman. 1 received Lewis into custody—there were four examinations—Cruttenden was first in custody, and was ad
mitted to bail by the Magistrate, after making a statement—the boy, Smith, was first examined on the second examination—he was remanded for the boy's attendance.

WILLIAM THOMAS SMITH
re-examined. I told my mother about this directly I left the place, that same morning—I told James Wheeler directly I saw him—it was more than a week after that I went before the Justice—I do not think anybody pointed out Isaacs to me—the policeman asked me whether that was the man—I directly said, "Yes"—I believed it was him—I have no doubt of him—I knew him well before—I told Wheeler, who had been there—I did not know where Isaacs lived—I knew his name—I told Wheeler next morning that I had seen Isaacs there.

(Thomas Jennings, ships' anchor-maker, Rotherhithe, deposed to Lewis's good character: and John Edwards, wholesale stationer, No. 5, Little St. Thomas the Apostle; and Lewis Nathan, clothes salesman, Paternoster-row, to that of Isaacs.)

ISAACS**—
GUILTY .—
Transported for Fifteen Years.

LEWIS—
GUILTY .—Recommended to mercy by the Jury and Prosecutor.

1391.
JOHN IRELAND , was indicted
for embezzling 1l. 5s. 1d., which he had received on account of
William Arnold, his master; to which he pleaded

GUILTY . Aged 40.—
Confined Six Months.

1392.
CHARLES RUFFLES , was indicted
for stealing, on the 21st of March, 1 pair of stays, value 2s., the goods of
James Hunter; and 2 frocks, 5s., the goods of
William Jupp.

ELIZABETH JUPP . I am the wife of William Jupp, and live in Union-street, Clapham-road. The prisoner lodged in my house—I missed two frocks on the 23rd of March—these are them—I found them in the basket produced.
ANN HUNTER . I am the wife of James Hunter—I lodge at Mrs. Jupp's. I lost this pair of stays out of a box in my bed-room, on the 21st of March.
BENJAMIN ROGERS . On the 21st of March the prisoner brought a basket to my house, containing some articles, but what I did not know—he asked me

the favour to leave them there for a day or two, on account of his landlady and his wife having some words—I took it into my room, and afterwards took it to Mrs. Jupp's, containing all the articles which the prisoner bad brought in it, excepting what he and his wife had taken out—no one but them bad an op
portunity of putting anything into it.
Prisoner's Defence. I do not know these things; I never took them from any person; I never was in Mrs. Hunter's apartment.
(The prisoner received a good character.)

GUILTY . Aged 28.—Recommended to mercy.—
Confined Two Months.

1393.
MARTHA RUFFLES , was indicted
for stealing, on the 23rd of March, 1 petticoat, value 1s., the goods of
William Jupp.
ELIZABETH JUPP . Amongst other things, I lost a petticoat out of a box or a drawer in my bed-room—this is it.

Prisoner. There are more petticoats alike than one. Witness. I am sure this is mine—there was a body to it, which is in a parcel here—I have no doubt about it—I saw it on the prisoner's person at the cell at the station.

GEORGE BECK (police-constable V 63.) I took the prisoner on the 23rd of March—I found this petticoat coming off her feet while she was in custody at the Clapham station—she went out of the front-room into the cell, and pulled off the petticoat there.
Prisoner. I hope mercy will be shown me.

GUILTY . Aged 23.—Recommended to mercy.—
Confined One Month.

1394.
JAMES PONEY , was indicted
for feloniously receiving, on the 27th of Feb., 41bs. weight of pork, value 2s.; and 21bs. weight of butter, 2s.; the goods of
Daniel Thompson, well knowing them to have been stolen; and that he had been before convicted of felony.

FRANCES FINCH . I am single, and live with my sister. On the 26th of Feb. I put a boiled leg of pork into a safe at the back of Mr. David Thomp
son's premises, and next morning it was gone.

JOHN EASTON . I live with my father, in Greyhound-place, Lambeth. On the 27th of Feb. Charles Godchild came to my house, and said something to me—at seven o'clock in the morning he came again, and showed me some boiled pork—the prisoner was with Godchild, and asked him if he wanted to sell it—Godchild said, yes, and asked him 1s. for it—the prisoner said, "I will give you 10d."—he gave him 6d. then, and 4d. more in the afternoon.

Q. How was the prisoner to know that it was stolen? A. Because Godchild told him he had had a pull—that means it was stolen—that was be
fore he bought it—there was about 3 1/2 lbs. of it.

WILLIAM EDMEAD . I am a policeman. I took Godchild, and he pleaded guilty to stealing this pork—the prisoner was at that time in custody for an assault, and I could not take him then, but when I did take him he said he did not wish to have anything to do with the pork, but Godchild brought it.
Prisoner. I never had anything to do with it; when the lad said he had had a pull I told him to be off.

JOHN EASTON
re-examined. He did buy it in my presence—he put it under one side of his jacket, and two pounds of butter on the other, in my father's back room.

ROBERT EMMERSON (police-sergeant V 9.) I produce a certificate of the prisoner's former conviction, which I got at the office of the Clerk of the Peace for Surrey—(read)—the prisoner is the person then tried and convicted.

GUILTY . * Aged 20.—
Transported for Seven Years.

1395.
JOHN DONOVAN,
JOHN CONNOR , and
JAMES DAVIS , were indicted for
unlawfully uttering counterfeit coin.

CHARLES BERRY (police-constable V 59.) About eight o'clock in the evening, of the 20th of March, I was on duty at Nine Elms—I saw the three prisoners going towards Mr. White's house, and within 300 yards of it—they were in conversation together.

JOHN WHITE . On the 20th of March, about nine o'clock in the evening, Donovan came to my house, and asked for a pennyworth of bread—I served him—he gave roe a sixpence, which I immediately saw was bad—I asked where he got it—he said from his brother, in the public-house—I told him to go and fetch his brother—I kept the sixpence, and he went out—I went out, but could not see him—I told the policeman about it, and gave him the six
pence after I had marked it.

MARIA EGGLETON . My husband is a tobacconist, and lives in Belmont-row, Vauxhall. About half-past nine o'clock, on the 20th of March, Donovan and Connor came to the shop—Donovan asked for a halfpennyworth of tobacco, and Connor said, "We may as well have a pennyworth"—I served them—Donovan gave me a sixpence—I gave the change—they put their hands be
hind them, divided the tobacco, and tossed which should have the biggest half—directly they got outside the shop they ran, seeing that I looked at the sixpence, and found it was bad—I gave it to my servant for a short time, and told her to go after them, and get the tobacco back if she could—she returned, and gave me the sixpence—about a quarter of an hour after I saw the pri
soners in custody—I gave the sixpence to the officer.

ELIZABETH ANN NICHOLAS . I am a servant to Mrs. Eggleton. I re
ceived a sixpence from her on the 20th of March, and went after the prisoners I gave the same sixpence back to my mistress.

JOHN ANDREWS (police-constable V 46.) A little after nine o'clock on this evening, I saw Davis going towards Mrs. Eggleton's shop—Donovan and Connor were running after him, and one of them called out "Jemmy"—Davis stopped—I walked 150 yards, and Mr. White gave me this sixpence—Davis stopped, and the two others overtook him, and I did not see any more of them—Mr. White gave me a description corresponding to Donovan—I pointed to the direction the three had gone—White went in that di
rection—about a quarter of an hour after I saw Davis and Donovan standing at the corner of the Nine Elms—I watched—they went to the Southampton Arms, and came out with Connor, and all three went together to Vauxhall-gate—they stopped a little way down the road—I still kept sight of them till I saw Bent—I then took Connor and Donovan, and Bent took Davis—as soon as Bent took Davis I saw something drop from his hand—I turned on my light, and saw three sixpences on the ground—I then found another—I took up one of them, and Bent took the others—I then went to Eggleton's—when we got to White's I searched Davis, and found 5d. in copper on him.

THOMAS BENT (police-constable P 95.) I assisted in taking the pri
soners—I found 4d. in copper on Donovan, and 1s. 1d. on Connor—I took Davis—he dropped four sixpences—I took up three of them—Mrs. Eggleton gave me this other one.
MR. JOHN FIELD . I am inspector of coin to the Mint—these are all counterfeit—three are cast in one mould and three in another.
Connor's Defence. I was selling things as I had no work to do, and coming out of the Southampton Arms I met Donovan and Davis.
Davis. I never went about with such things.

DONOVAN,—
GUILTY . Aged 15.

CONNOR,—
GUILTY . Aged 16.

DAVIS,—
GUILTY . Aged 18.

1396.
GEORGE HAYNES , was indicted
for uttering counterfeit coin.

RICHARD SANDWELL . I am a publican, and live in High-street, Lambeth. On the 2nd of March the prisoner came for some beer—he tendered a half-crown—I put it into a bowl—there were a few sixpences there, but no other half-crown—I gave him change and he went away—a few minutes after I went to the till—there was no one there but me—I took out the half-crown, and found it was bad—I marked it and put it into my pocket—on the 4th he came again for a pint of porter—he tendered another half-crown—I saw it was bad—he went into the tap-room—I did not say any thing, but sent for an officer and gave him the two half-crowns.
ALEXANDER TAHOURDIN (police-constable L 57.) I was at Mr. Sandwell's on the evening of the 4th, and took the prisoner—I found nothing on him—I produce two half-crowns which Sandwell gave me.
MR. JOHN FIELD . These are both counterfeit.
Prisoner's Defence. I never was in the shop but once.

GUILTY . * Aged 22.—
Confined One Year.

1397.
WILLIAM PIGGOTT , was indicted
for embezzlement.
ELIZABETH ANN BECKLEY . I know Mr. Chapple—I was in the habit of dealing with him in 1842—this bill has been sent to me by him—on the 26th of May the prisoner called on me, and I paid him 1s. 6d.

Cross-examined by MR. DOANE. Q. Have you any recollection of the day except from looking at the back of this bill? A. Yes; when we pay the whole of these tallies, we take it back to the shop—the whole comes to 2l. 2s. 5d.
FRANCES JANE Goss. This bill was owing to Mr. Chapple, the linen draper, in Great Dover-street, before I married. On the 22nd of June I paid the prisoner 1s.
Cross-examined. Q. You have paid a good many sums, have you not? A. Yes; all on the back of this bill—I see that he marks off whatever I pay him.
MARY MOORE . I have purchased articles of Mr. Chapple, the linen-draper, in Great Dover-street—in Nov. I paid the prisoner 1s. 6d.
Cross-examined. Q. You have made a great many payments on account of your tally, have you not? A. Yes.

THOMAS CHAPPLE . I am a linen-draper. I live in Great Dover-street, Borough. The prisoner was in my service in 1842—he was in the habit of collecting money on my account—he had a collecting book to take out in the morning, with certain names inserted in it, and as he received these monies it was his duty to insert them in this book at the time, and when he re
turned turned at night he generally gave us a duplicate of his monies which he had received in the course of the day—we generally send a bill with every parcel of goods sent out, and either I or my young men call on the customers for their weekly payments—on the 26th of May, 1842, the prisoner received by his book, 1l. 12s.—it ought to have been that day 1l. 12s. 6d.—this is the collecting book in which he ought to put it down—I know by Mrs. Beckley's hill that she paid 1s. 6d. that day—the aggregate of all the money was

1l. 12s. 6d. that day according to her bill—on the 22nd of June he received 1s. from Mrs. Goss, and that was inserted in the book after it was made up can tell so by the addition—after the shilling was inserted the addition was incorrect—the books were generally kept by a clerk—on the 22nd of June there was 1s. from Mrs. Goss, which was not accounted for—the amount was 19s. 6d.—the book including that was 20s. 6d., so there was 1s. short—on the 2nd of Nov. there was 6d. short from Mrs. Moore.

Cross-examined. Q. When did the prisoner come into your service? A. At the end of 1839—he came on trial first, and then he became my ap
prentice—I had a partner named Thomas Hutchinson—we have dissolved partnership—he is alive and well, I believe—we ceased to be partners on the 19th of last April—I have understood that would be an end of the prisoner's apprenticeship.

Q. Did the prisoner talk of leaving you after he was free? A. I believe I first gave him warning about a fortnight prior to his giving me warning to leave, which was in Feb.—I did not induce him to stay by offering to raise his wages—I will not swear I did not—he may have made two journies in a week, and sometimes one, after these customers—the number of distinct per
sons he would have to call on would depend on the number we have—he would have to call on forty, fifty, or sixty in a day—he might probably on a Monday have to call on two hundred, to collect these sums of 1s., 1s. 6d., or 6d., or half-a-crown.

Q. Has it not happened sometimes that the prisoner has paid an excess of money from what he has received? A. Not on these days—it is very pro
bable that sometimes he might have paid more than he received—such a thing might happen as that, out of these two or three hundred items—he has omitted to put down the 1s. or 6d. in one column, but has put it to another person, and that would account for the excess—the columns in this book represent customers—this book lasts six months—here are different columns, in which the entries ought to be made—such a thing might have happened that the entries have been made the next day, but it was unknown to me—I do not recollect your putting to me at the office an enormous number that had got under the wrong head—I had not time to examine this book every night—it has been left to my clerk—the prisoner might have paid me sixpence on the 26th of May—I will not venture to swear ha did not pay me the sixpence—I generally received the money at night; if not, the first thing in the morning—I have an account of the money I received—I do not enter every night myself what money I receive from each; but if not, I do it in the morn
ing—sometimes it is done by the clerk—there were three examinations of this case before Mr. Trail, the Magistrate.

Q. Did he tell you his opinion, when you had gone throngh the whole case the last time, that it was a matter of mistake? A. No sir, I do not re
collect his expressing that as his opinion—I do not recollect that he gave me his opinion—he took a great deal of trouble to look over the book with me—I think I gave the prisoner warning about Feb., 1843—he left me about the middle of the month.

Q. Did you detain his boxes? A. I did, sir—boxes he had none, sir—I never saw his boxes—I detained some things of his, I cannot tell what they were in or what the things were—I considered I had reason to detain them—when I came home at night from collecting, there were some parcels for him to take out, and he said he would not take them out for me or any other person—he had given me warning to leave, and wanted to leave directly—he at the same time asked for his wages—I said I should go through his books

and examine his accounts—that was my reason for detaining his goods—he made application to me afterwards for them, and I was summoned to Union-hall—he made application to me again, in presence of his father—the first time I saw him, after he insisted on leaving me—I met him in Blackman-street—I met the prisoner at the Bull's Head, Camberwell, a month ago, last Thursday—he was in company with his father—Mr. and Mrs. Pounsford were there—the prisoner then again applied to me for his wages—that was the time I spoke of, and I said he had been receiving monies, and not accounting for them—I might probably say, "You have been robbing me"—he said, "Why don't you take me up, and prefer a charge against me, if you have any?"—I know he was at that time living at Messrs. Milson and Coats', who are in my line of business.

Q. Have you ever got in any trouble yourself? A. No, I never shut my
self up from the gaze of this world for a short time, that I know of—I know Mr. Martin very well—I was in his service once, along with a person named Piper—Mr. Martin and I had a fall out—I never fell into a cellar, nor shut myself up—I never knew that there was a charge, and the police were after me—I never shut myself up—I know a person named Flight—I was never locked up in his house, nor in Bosier's house—I lived with Mr. Martin eight years—an old man came into his service, we had a quarrel, and I left—I never stopped in Bosier's house—I never lived in his house for three weeks, nor for three hours—I lived with Mr. Martin eight years, and left him—he sent for me to come back, with an advance of salary—I went back, and stopped some time after that.

Q. Now from the 9th of March, when you charged the prisoner at the Bull's Head with his accounts being wrong, did you do anything to take proceedings against him? A. No—on the 14th I received a letter from a solicitor, that legal proceedings would be taken against me, unless I paid the prisoner's wages on or before the 16th, but I did not take notice of the letter—I think it was not on the 16th that I had the prisoner taken into custody on this charge, but I will not swear it was not.

MR. WYLDE. Q. My friend took a deal of trouble to convince the Ma
gistrate of his view of the case? A. Yes, I and Mr. Martin had a quarrel—I left him, and he induced me to go back at a larger salary—I returned, and had 5s. a week additional—and more than that, I am doing business for him now—a mistake might happen in the columns—I never heard from the prisoner that he had made a mistake—I had to look over a great number of accounts before I found out these defalcations.

JOHN WOODHOUSE (police-sergeant M 13.) 1 took the prisoner on Thurs
day, the 16th of March.
Cross-examined. Q. Did you find him at Milson and Coates'? A. Yes, he said, "I wonder Mr. Chapple did not charge me before;" and he said it was all through spite.
NOT GUILTY .
ADJOURNED TO MONDAY, MAY 8TH, 1843.

div0.p: The following prisoners, upon whom the Judgement of the Court was respited, have been sentenced as under:—
Frederick Redman... Page 44... Confined Five Days.
John Baker... " 158... Transported for Seven Years—Parkhurst.
Isaac Livermore... " 138... Transported for Seven Years.
Thomas Hamer Morris... " 154... Confined Eighteen Months.
Frederick Charles B. Blackwell... " 607... Transported for Ten Years.
Thomas Harris Pitman... " 865... Confined One Year.
Thomas Charles Jackson... " 935... Confined One Day.
William Harvey... " 1055... Confined Fourteen Days, and Twice Whipped.
